139395: Burrenton Forge-Tender.author: Zoah
139395: Burrenton Forge-Tender.text_parsed:
Sigh... I hate these anti color cards. it makes the game... so... Much... more irksome. Put simply, I don't want to play a game where I might not be able to win because my opponent structured a deck to eat my color.

At the very least, if someone wants to structure a deck to beat me, they shouldn't have a color coded cards to do it. If someone want's to beat me, I think they should have to work to do it.

and just to prove that I'm not whining that this card beat me: I never play red, blue is my color.

139395: Burrenton Forge-Tender.author: Lord_Sauron
139395: Burrenton Forge-Tender.text_parsed:
Why are people complaining about this being a hate card?

Red has an incredible amount of overpowered cards like Lightning Bolt, Chain Lightning, Price of Progress etc. Decks purely containing such damage spells are even winning Legacy tournaments nowadays.
The last couple of years, it has been made soooo easy to play dual or even tripple color decks, that almost everybody splashed a bit of red in his/her deck just to use this damage spells.
Blue has it's Merfolks; the Wizards apparently decided that it MUST be the strongest tribal deck, otherwise they wouldn't have made 3 Merfolk Lords.
Black gets more and more turn one discard options plus looking at the opponent's hand, which makes discard decks certainly an alternative.

Green and white did not get such an overpowered 'characteristic' yet, so it is logical that the Wizards are designing cards like this: otherwise noone would play those colors anymore.

139396: Plover Knights.author: Equinox523
139396: Plover Knights.text_parsed: Context is everything. This is an excellent card in Limited, and in its environment, it offered some much-needed air support to the kithkin decks and also finished tons of games. Furthermore, it's a common - obviously foolish to compare it to uncommon Serra Angel or Baneslayer Angel - meaning you could easily snap up multiple copies if you drafted white. Furthermore, Lorwyn lacked many huge flyers, so having this at common made it really good at both offense and defense.

139401: Lys Alana Huntmaster.author: MagnusMtG
139401: Lys Alana Huntmaster.text_parsed:
I'm surprised to see so many positive comments here about this card. I expected at least a few Huntmaster haters . .

Anyway, I like it. I think it's ok, but I find that by the time I have 4 mana to spend (which is nearly immediately 'cause, ya know.. elves..) I'd rather cast something else. I pack 2 in my Elves deck, which has 4 Bramblewood Paragons and 3 Imperious Perfects.

Huntmaster + Paragon + Perfect = 5/5 trampler. (Wren's Run Vanquisher is a 4-of for this same level of threat).

I've tried out Obsidian Battle-Axe to further synergize with the warrior-tribal theme (Paragon + Perfect + Axe = 7/6 trampling, hasty Huntmaster (or death-touching Vanquisher), but found that it's better to just pack more elf spells instead.

And my understanding is that if you cast Elvish Promenade with Huntmaster on the field, Prom-night triggers Huntmaster before it resolves, and that's an additional token to double.

139404: Lammastide Weave.author: Zuty
139404: Lammastide Weave.text_parsed:
Zuty's Random Card of the Day #3:

Lammastide Weave is currently the ONLY green mill card; unless you count self-mill with Dredge. There's really no downside to this card:

-It mills the top card of someones deck
-There is the potential to gain life
-You draw a card

-I Temporal Spring your and then Lammastide Weave naming that card.
-I Ponder and put my Emrakul second from the top and then name it with Lammastide Weave after I draw from the Ponder.
-I Brainstorm and put Draco on the top of my deck and then name it with Lammastide Weave.
-I play Field of Dreams and name your top card with Lammastide Weave.

or

I take a stab at it and play Lammastide Weave naming Jace, the Mind Sculptor: -Cool your Jace is now gone, I gain 4 life, and draw a card.
-Dang, Jace wasn't there. Oh well, still got rid of your next card and I still get to draw.

Fairly priced. Does beneficial stuff regardless of you naming the right card. In an odd color which makes it different (opponent won't see mill coming from a green card). And it's just a good card. I like it.

4.5/5

~Zuty

139406: Judge of Currents.author: Ideatog
139406: Judge of Currents.text_parsed:
That infinite combo you hate so much costs 3 cards, two of which are 1 toughness creatures (before the shields). Even if you have no removal and no burn with which to get rid of those creatures, it only gets him infinite life, which doesn't help him win. You could use any number of infinite damage combos to just kill him, or use poison, or use a win condition card like Barren Glory or Mortal Combat. As OverfiendSurprise said, don't hate.

It is also only playable in the eternal formats. Legacy, and especially Vintage both have much , much nastier monsters (I'm looking at you flash-protean hulk).

139410: Bog-Strider Ash.author: TheWrathofShane
139410: Bog-Strider Ash.text_parsed:
This guy is funky. Not only are the ability's weird, but when playing with goblins you want to unload your hand as fast as possible. You cannot take advantage of his ability fast enough, you need to summon goblins after you drop him, and most goblins are 1-3 drop that want to be out fast. Not only that, you have to feed a green mana to use it, and 2 life is not worth the hassle at all.

Perhaps you can come up with a bounce engine plus Raging Goblin and this guy, but then congrats you are using at least 3 cards + to gain 2 life a turn!!!!!

Not good a good card at all, but then again they all cant be winners.

139414: Oblivion Ring.author: CorkBulb
139414: Oblivion Ring.text_parsed:
The "what creature is that in the art" debate has been raging on for several posts and the answer has not been found as of this post. It's obviously a Vengeful Firebrand, which was released long after Lorwyn, so I can understand the confusion. The two swords and sheathes match, as well as the scale-mail bracers and overall female flamekin body. I love cards that involve art of other cards or from the main story!

Anyway, IMHO, O-ring is the best white removal available. For O-Ring gets rid of not just creatures, but also Planeswalkers, artifacts, other enchantments (including other O-rings!) which is very hard to do with other spells, especially in other colors, without a major drawback. Its cost often messes up your tempo if played early, but if you absolutely have to get rid of something immediately (Wellwisher anyone?) it's well worth it. And, of course, you can always hold it and wait to play it at just the right moment, such as removing that last blocker for the win attack or sending that huge creature your opponent just played to oblivion.

The major disadvantage is that it remains on the battlefield and can get bounced or burned itself, and will trigger any enter-the-battlefield abilities of both the card removed, and other cards already on the battlefield. Also, it's an enchantment, so it can only be cast during your turn, and can't be used in combat or in response to something an opponent does.

I find the versatility of this card overrides any drawbacks. You have to assume your opponent can get rid of it, or even cares to. It also will remove and enchantments or counters on the creature, and the creature can't regenerate to save itself either. Nobody will want to burn an O-ring to recover their removed Joraga Warcaller after the counters are lost, so the creature is as good as dead. Any other similar counter-oriented card will suffer from the O-ring (such as modular/sunburst creatures) Also, any equipment will have to be re-equipped. The tempo loss from that alone plus the enchantment burn will surely mess up your opponent.

Cards like Path to Exile and Swords to Plowshares are great 1-drop white removals, but come with drawbacks. Path mana accelerates and land filters your opponent (unless in the rare case that you're landlocked and use it on yourself), which I find to be a significant drawback because now you opponent has an extra land of his color-choice that he didn't draw and is ahead of you mana wise. STP is good if you blast a relatively weak creature (with a special ability or something) but bad if its a fatty because then your opponent gets a lot of life. And, of course, you can blast your own creature if you absolutely need the life.

And then there is Journey to Nowhere, which is less to cast but only targets creatures. Also a very good white removal.

There are plenty of multicolored removal spells, such as the famous Vindicate, which compete for mono-colored removal in a multicolored deck, but that would be a whole different story now.

White removal is abundant in the metagame, but I think that O-ring is one of the best. I typically run 4 in every white deck I build unless I can find an appropriate multicolored spell to fit the deck.

I also like the Lorwyn art better than the newer version, It just seems more like a "Oh noes! Ive been sent to oblivion!" picture.

139414: Oblivion Ring.author: mUrielw
139414: Oblivion Ring.text_parsed: The sugar thing is an interesting example of anachronism in folklore, because access to granulated sugar in the British Isles (except as an exotic luxury) only arrived with the advent of mass slavery in the Caribbean and advances in technology - long, long after the period that would later be romanticized into the basis for Lorwyn had passed. Beet sugar arrived even later than that, once granulated sugar had become a staple part of the European diet but Emancipation pushed up its price, but since what we've seen of Lorwyn's climate (and can infer from its real-world basis) is much better-suited to the cultivation of beets than sugar cane, and extracting sucrose from the former is actually a bit lower-tech than the latter, and if they meant like honey or something they would have said so, I feel like it's a safe conclusion that the sugar referenced in the flavor text is beet sugar - assuming it's not some magical granulated pollen extract or the like.
139414: Oblivion Ring.text_posted: The sugar thing is an interesting example of anachronism in folklore, because access to granulated sugar in the British Isles (except as an exotic luxury) only arrived with the advent of mass slavery in the Caribbean and advances in technology - long, long after the period that would later be romanticized into the basis for Lorwyn had passed. Beet sugar arrived even later than that, once granulated sugar had become a staple part of the European diet but Emancipation pushed up its price, but since what we've seen of Lorwyn's climate (and can infer from its real-world basis) is much better-suited to the cultivation of beets than sugar cane, and extracting sucrose from the former is actually a bit lower-tech than the latter, and if they meant like honey or something they would have said so, I feel like it's a safe conclusion that the sugar referenced in the flavor text is beet sugar - assuming it's not some magical granulated pollen extract or the like.

I'm building a merfolk islandwalk deck right now, and this guy has three slots reserved for him. He's good tempo- keeps the pain coming. After he drops, I've got an expendable soldier as well. With a Merfolk Sovereign on the field, he becomes an evasive 3/4 soldier. I could bring another Sovereign to the top of the deck, or even another Summon the School for extra creature advantage. I'd say this card is pretty solid, as it becomes part o the glue that holds the deck together. For the purpose it was created for, I give it a 5/5. It doesn't stand up very well on it's own though. Needs teamwork to become what he can. For that reason, I give it a 3.5/5. Altogether, 4/5, solid card.

139420: Merrow Harbinger.author: merigold
139420: Merrow Harbinger.text_parsed:
@narim - pair him with Drowner of Secrets and Fallowsage - He comes into play, you put the desired merfolk on top of your library, tap him for drowner, draw a card that you just put on top of your library. With Fallowsage in play, you can draw another card. With Intruder Alarm in play, you can untap after you cast the new merfolk. If you have Judge of Currents in play, you gain life and if you have Stonybrook Schoolmaster in play, you have an infinite combo.

Tap Schoolmaster to the DoS, JoCurrents gets you a life, you mill the opponent for a card, tap Fallowsage to to mill and draw a card, Intruder Alarm triggers on the new merfolk from Schoolmaster and all your merfolk are untapped, so you do it again... and again and again...

139420: Merrow Harbinger.author: bowlofgumbo
139420: Merrow Harbinger.text_parsed: I run a couple in my Merfolk deck in spite of his being a little over-costed and a little under-powered. Luckily, there's a plethora of viable options at earlier points on the Merfolk curve, so I'm usually not too disappointed when I stumble upon the Harbinger. More often than not, the implicit card advantage that comes from choosing my next draw (after all, there's no explicit card advantage when you harbinge because you don't actually get more cards; however, you do gain the advantage of card quality) outweighs the drawback of his four-mana-costing, puny 2/3 frame.

139429: Spellstutter Sprite.author: Dreki
139429: Spellstutter Sprite.text_parsed: Yes this card counts itself for the effect. Here is an example of how that works: Cast Spellstutter sprite >Spellstutter enters play > the effect goes on the stack > the effect looks at the board for all creatures with the subtype faerie you control > the effect see's Spellstutter so it's automatically 1+X where 1 is Spellstutter and x is the rest of your faeries > effect resolves. One of the best commons in blue in my opinion because you can put it in any blue deck for those pesky 1 and 2 cost spells you don't want to waste your Force Of Will on ^.^
139429: Spellstutter Sprite.text_posted: Yes this card counts itself for the effect. 139429: Spellstutter Sprite.author: Zoah
139429: Spellstutter Sprite.text_parsed:
This card was the inspiration for my current best deck: a mono blue faerie flash deck.
It's, put simply, the best card in the deck.

It has everything. It has flight and 1 power, making it eligible to be a sword. With it's flash, by itself, it means that I don't have to worry about wasting manna when holding for a counter. In fact, it actually does the counter.

By itself, it's a two cost soft counter that gives me a creature.
In a faerie deck, the counter is basically a hard counter.
5/5

139429: Spellstutter Sprite.author: wesleyv
139429: Spellstutter Sprite.text_parsed:
Great combo withGlen Elendra Pranksers. Just get two sprites by bouncing Faerie Harbinger in and out. Combine with Stonybrook banneret to play all of your counter faeiries for {U}, and bam, you have two, or even three opponents completely locked down with as many counters as you can pay for.

I ususally clean up the board by running Vedalken Æthermage. You can use it's wizard cycling to grab the last faerie wizard you need for your combo, or you can use the much underrated imagecrafter to turn the enemy creature into a sliver and stuff it into their hand on their turn using the aethermage, and countering it when they try to recast. Throw in an information dealer to grab unsummon or whatever else you need with all those wizards in play, and when you have enough mana left over, drop a faerie swarm for the muscle to finish them.

This is a wonderful card for a mono blue faerie deck, 5/5.

139429: Spellstutter Sprite.author: DmitryM
139429: Spellstutter Sprite.text_parsed:
Oh hi there, I see you are trying to cast lightning bolt on my delver of secrets, let me change your mind while putting up a threat on the board. Don't worry you can try again next turn, and the turn after, and the turn after, probably not the turn after because you are probably dead.

Seriously though, does anybody have any idea how to counter this? It's like playing a game where anytime you play anything, they (1) counter it (2) counter it AND use that counter as a threat against you.

Worse, anytime you try to counter it, they will counter your counter, then you counter the counter to your counter and they counter the counter... my head hurts but you get the idea.

Totally gamebreaking in Pauper.

139435: Faerie Trickery.author: sporvan
139435: Faerie Trickery.text_parsed: In addition to being the tricksieyest tribe of them all, Faeries excel at removing cards from graveyards with powerful cards such as Faerie Macabre and Puppeteer Clique. The often forgotten Faerie Trickery is another tool in the Fae arsenal which not only counters a spell but removes it from the game entirely. However, due to the popularity of the Faerie tribe, this spell isn't seeing much play in the metagame since it can't counter Faerie spells. If it wasn't for this it would almost always be better than Cancel.

139440: Footbottom Feast.author: uoldgoat
139440: Footbottom Feast.text_parsed:
What, you mean to tell me "Footbottom Feast" is not an appropriate card name in the world of Innistrad, so they had to create a functional reprint with Gravepurge?

Seriously though, this card is a rockstar in my BG Relentless Rats / Thrumming Stone deck. One game an opponent had taken out 15 of my rats with a Steel Hellkite. The next turn I top-decked a Concordant Crossroads, played it, followed up with a Footbottom Feast & a Relentless rat (bringing the other 14 back out), and finished off both of my opponents. It was great - and a rare situation where I actually wanted to play an instant when I could play a sorcery in order to get that extra non-creature draw.

139445: Boggart Shenanigans.author: Rasher

@ wolfv
I thought so too, but if you do some research you'll find that those 1/1 goblin tokens, such as those produced by dragon fodder and siege-gang commander dont actually go to the graveyard when they are sacrificed because they are tokens, not creature cards themselves and are simply removed from play when they leave the battlefield, the same is true of all tokens, now if the card said "when ever another goblin you control dies" instead of "is put in to a grave yard from play" this card would be easily one of the best goblin cards around, especially when paired with mog infestation. Sadly as it stands its only good for non-token based sacrificial suicide goblin builds

139449: Eyeblight's Ending.author: Henrietta
139449: Eyeblight's Ending.text_parsed:
Worse than doomblade in most situations because it costs 50% extra mana.

Also, Eyeblight's Ending vs. Rend Flesh comes down to how you build your deck. If you build a deck that can make use of the fact that this card is an Elf, it's better. If you build a deck that can make use of Arcane spells, Rend Flesh is better. If you build a deck that does neither, Rend Flesh is better.

139454: Black Poplar Shaman.author: Hereditist
139454: Black Poplar Shaman.text_parsed:
I don't see why this card is rated so low. I run this in my treefollk edh deck, and it kicks some serious ass.

Especially late game, I'll have a Timber Protector out, and I'll leave 3 mana open for any targeted removal. Otherwise, I'm usually even safe from board wipes. Great as commander back up as well.

Yes, perhaps not the most versatile card ever, but definitely usable in a treefolk deck. Great edh material.

3.5/5

139468: Heat Shimmer.author: Mode

this card is similar to a one-use Kiki-Jiki, Mirror Breaker ability, with two differences.
the first one being that you can copy a legend, thus containing a hidden Hero's Demise effect.
the second one is the way this token gets removed. since it won't be sacrified like you have to do it in regards of Kiki-Jiki, this one won't trigger "p.i.g."-effects, unless you have another option to get rid of the token.

139474: Giant Harbinger.author: humor_love
139474: Giant Harbinger.text_parsed:
Uh, this guy is a Giant who tutors for another Giant. There's Bloodshot Cyclops, Valleymaker, Borderland Behemoth, Sunrise Sovereign, and Hamletback Goliath. That's a pretty good pool to choose from. Don't forget the classic Craw Giant. He's strong, too.

If you're having trouble getting enough mana to cast him, one of two things is likely to be the problem. The first thing that could be wrong is that you're playing fast or competitive one-on-one Magic. You should stop that. The second problem you could be having is not designing your deck to be capable of producing lots of mana. If you have a 5-costed 3/4 tutor creature, you're gonna need to put cards in your deck that help get more mana. If you make sure to address these two issues (fast Magic and/or lack of mana boost), you should be okay, and ready for some fun games of Magic. Enjoy!

139483: Moonglove Winnower.author: Kryptnyt
139483: Moonglove Winnower.text_parsed:
It's an elf, but that doesn't necessarily make it great. Elves are notorious for being killed by spells that cost four mana; Wrath of God, Moat, Damnation, Humility... it's important for your tempo to have as many cheap to cast elves as you can and win before they can drop things that kill your entire army. A 4 to cast elf with Deathtouch is certainly playable in limited, but with cards like Thornweald Archer and Wren's Run Vanquisher already in green, you have to ask yourself if this card is worth your time.
Having said that, 2/3 is my personal favorite power and toughness ratio of all time. Just seems like solid numbers.

139489: Spring Cleaning.author: music.hate
139489: Spring Cleaning.text_parsed:
This card gets five stars for flavor and politics in EDH. You get to choose which opponent you clash with, letting two players (yourself and target player) "scry 1," and if you win everyone else with enchantments on board loses. For (1G) this seems like a steal at instant speed.

Put this in a big stompy deck with a commander like Mayael the Anima to hedge your bet for that top-deck.

139492: Cloudcrown Oak.author: Hancocky
139492: Cloudcrown Oak.text_parsed:
@ Tiggurix

"Oak Treefolk

The oaks are the largest and strongest of all treefolk, and are the greatest warriors of their kind. So powerful are they that even the mighty giants are no match for them. Oaks are also the most philosophical treefolk.

The tallest oak treefolk are called cloudcrowns. These are so tall they can swat aerial attackers straight out of the sky, and as such kithkin prefer to build their homes near their domiciles. "

Source: http://wiki.mtgsalvation.com/article/Treefolk#Lorwyn_Treefolk

Based on that, I suppose all the other kinds of Treefolk races on Lorwyn are not tall enough to attack most fliers.

139494: Oakgnarl Warrior.author: feeble2002
139494: Oakgnarl Warrior.text_parsed:
Good card for re-animator, great for peasant and pauper re-animator. There are few common beasties to pick from, and this is one of the best. If it was a 5/7 with just trample, it would be a typical common beast. But 5/7 with trample and vigilance puts him into the great category. He is the 2nd best common fattie, only below Ulamog's Crusher.

If you want a large creature with vigilance and trample, consider this card. There is currently only one other card that matches his size/toughness with these traits: Akroma, Angel of Wrath. That is a very elite group! Excellent art too. Very underrated. rating: 4.5/5
139494: Oakgnarl Warrior.text_posted:
Good card for re-animator, great for peasant and pauper re-animator. There are few common beasties to pick from, and this is one of the best. If it was a 5/7 with just trample, it would be a typical common beast. But 5/7 with trample [i]and vigilance[/i] puts him into the great category. He is the 2nd best common fattie, only below [autocard]Ulamog's Crusher[/autocard]. 

If you want a large creature with vigilance and trample, consider this card. There is currently only one other card that matches his size/toughness with these traits: [autocard]Akroma, Angel of Wrath[/autocard]. That is a very elite group!  Excellent art too. Very underrated. rating: 4.5/5

139494: Oakgnarl Warrior.author: nunzioni
139494: Oakgnarl Warrior.text_parsed: This card used to be good, until cost-effective green creatures came out. If you are going for a vanilla big creature, just use Terra Stomper. Ever since the Zendikar block came out, 5GG will get you a lot. My favorite card for that cost is Engulfing Slagwurm, a 7/7 creature with an ability better than deathtouch that gives you life whenever it fights. I could see using it in a treefolk creature type deck, but in a general green deck, it is kind of useless.

139495: Treefolk Harbinger.author: djflo
139495: Treefolk Harbinger.text_parsed:
nice little ramp for U/G:
T1 Forest, Llanowar Elves, Birds of Paradise or Noble Hierarch
T2 Island, play this and grab a forest, then Coiling Oracle, putting the forest into play. Then you could even play another one drop mana accelerant for six mana on turn 3.

Yes, there are faster, better ramps, but this leaves you with a few extra creatures, one of which is an excellent defender for early on.

139502: Fertile Ground.author: Gabriel422
139502: Fertile Ground.text_parsed:
I love Fertile Ground a lot - I've always hoped this will become evergreen like Llanowar Elves. Though it only appeared once in a core set, but it was reprinted enough times to make me happy.

The reason why this is usually better than Rampant - it gives you an extra mana once you get past 2 lands, by enchanting an untapped land. Though they're close, and each has its niche:

Rampant - cards that care about land count, landfall
Fertile Ground - Garruk.

139502: Fertile Ground.author: DoragonShinzui
139502: Fertile Ground.text_parsed:
Utopia Sprawl can only go on a forest, and can only tap for one color which you pick when you cast it. This can be placed on any land, and can switch colors as you need them.

There's a reason this costs more: It's more flexible.

139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.author: CeremonialBathory
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_parsed: @cats_and_me: Merieke Ri Berit's ability states that if she becomes untapped or leaves the battlefield, the creature she grants you control of is destroyed. In conjunction with this card, she would come in to play and steal a creature. Then, you'd pay and untap her using this card's ability. The stolen creature would be destroyed, and then you could tap her for another creature. You would not be able to gain control of two creatures, only one.
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_posted: @cats_and_me: [autocard]Merieke Ri Berit[/autocard]'s ability states that if she becomes [b]untapped[/b] or leaves the battlefield, the creature she grants you control of is destroyed. In conjunction with this card, she would come in to play and steal a creature. Then, you'd pay [1] and untap her using this card's ability. The stolen creature would be destroyed, and then you could tap her for another creature. You would not be able to gain control of two creatures, only one.

139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.author: cats_and_me
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_parsed:
After spending much time searching for creatures that benefit the most from this card, here are my three favourite suggestions: Merieke Ri Berit allows you to immediately gain control of two different creatures for four mana, Mangara Of Corondor allows you to immediately remove two different permanents from the game for four mana, and Royal Assassin allows you to immediately destroy two different tapped creatures for four mana! :) It's funny how your opponent doesn't get to untap before your assassin starts working..

Edit: Thanks everyone for rating my last comment high, but I'd like to edit it simply to answer to CeremonialBathory's comment.. You tap Merieke Ri Berit to gain control of a creature, and then you untap her in response to her tapping ability: Because it hasn't resolved, there's no creature that you've gained control of yet, so the second ability does nothing! :) You re-tap her to gain control of another creature, and then both tapping abilities resolve and you gain control of two different creatures, and with this card in play you can do this for four mana and immediately..

139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.author: Etsap
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_parsed:
@cats_and_me

I question the interpretation of Merieke Ri Berit's ability. The key is in the first sentence of the activated ability, which states that you gain control of the target creature for as long as you control Merieke. From the comprehensive rules:

611.2b Some continuous effects generated by the resolution of a spell or ability have durations worded "for as long as . . . ." If the "for as long as" duration never starts, or it ends before the moment the effect would first be applied, the effect does nothing. It doesn't start and immediately stop again, and it doesn't last forever.

So if you untap Merieke in response to her ability and use her again, then first activation of the ability does not grant you control of the targeted creature, because it ended before it was first applied. However, the destroy trigger is still created, so the next time Merieke untaps or leaves the battlefield, both of the targeted creatures get destroyed even though you never gained control of the first one you targeted.

P.S. - Avatar of Woe

139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.author: yyukichigai
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_parsed:
"Oh hi there, Jandor's Saddlebags. We looked at how lame you were and thought we'd give you the Voltaic Key treatment, but better."

1CMC and 1 for the untap effect would be great by itself, but throw in the pseudo-haste that applies only to activated abilities and this becomes a potential powerhouse. Lots of things to combo with: mana abilities (Priest of Titania), damage abilities (Prodigal Sorcerer), or just plain weird abilities (the aforementioned Merieke Ri Berit).

My current use for this is in a deck alongside Infect/poison creatures and enchantments like Fire Whip. Speeds things up wonderfully.

139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.author: Snafinturtle
139505: Thousand-Year Elixir.text_parsed:
@__silence__

Unfortunately your math is a little off, as the total mana at your disposal (it costs 1 to untap the creature) is 8. Close, but no cigar.

@Estap

Merieke's ability only stops working when you lose control of her, not when she becomes untapped. When she becomes untapped it destroys a creature taken control of by her, but that doesn't end her effect (assuming the creature doesn't die). Both creatures will still be subject to the destruction clause when she untaps, but they will both be taken control of.

139509: Springleaf Drum.author: Baconradar
139509: Springleaf Drum.text_parsed:
This card is HUGELY overrated.

Know why? Because people don't read it. Basically everyone seems to work on the false assumption that the card is broken, but they're completely ignoring that SPRINGLEAF DRUM HAS TO TAP.

That means unless you have a way of untapping your creature AND your artifact, for free, springleaf drum just gives one creature per turn the ability to tap for mana.

Now it's a good card, sure, but it's nowhere near broken and i'd say it's worse than a llanowar elf, for instance.

139509: Springleaf Drum.author: Gormaol
139509: Springleaf Drum.text_parsed: @Baconradar. Hahaha, you are such an idiot. Number one, it can't be targeted by creature removal, which is WIDELY prevalent in MANY competitive decks (Swords to Plowshares, Lightning Bolt, Chain Lightning, Snuff Out, Diabolic Edict, etc.). Number two, it's any type of mana, not just green, which in itself does not lend access to many of the best win condition cards in the format. Number three, your mana options will be continually targeted by many decks in the format, which makes each source of varied mana critical in many decks. Every competitive control deck incorporates land control elements (such as Wasteland, Life from the Loam, Sinkhole, and Knight of the Reliquary) that make any type of mana acceleration beyond the cost of 1 completely untenable in any type of deck. And the only decks that can actually viably run mana acceleration in any significant amount are storm decks, which in themselves are hugely risky and vulnerable because they can be brought down by a single spell, like Silence, Force of Will, or Spell Pierce, for example. Number four, as opposed to Paradise Mantle, you can pay for this card in turns before you have to actually use it, as it doesn't require the creature be in play before this can be put into play and be ready for use, which can and will make the difference whether you'll be able to get your key card piece into play.

139509: Springleaf Drum.text_parsed:
There is one thing that makes this card worthwhile, better than Paradise Mantle even: you can get one mana out of a just cast creature that you don't mind tapping (because of Springleaf Drum's wording).

In modern, turn 2:
Etherium Sculptor, free Springleaf Drum, almost any 2 CMC artifact including a possible second Etherium Sculptor.

In the correct context this card is mana acceleration, metalcraft fodder, and sacrifice fodder.

139509: Springleaf Drum.author: DoragonShinzui
139509: Springleaf Drum.text_parsed:
I prefer it to Paradise Mantle because it isn't locked onto a creature. I drop it once, and never have to worry 'bout it again. Paradise Mantle has a equip , which means for the same cost as this you get the same effect if you only have one creature you'll ever want to use for this. But if that's the case, you're doing it wrong. Why would you ever have a creature who's sole purpose is tapping for mana, but doesn't have a mana tapping ability itself?
What the drums do is allow you to use your early game one drops later to help fix and accelerate mana. Drop, say, a Flamekin Harbinger, and now it's no longer just a 1/1. It helps pay for whatever you decided to search for.
Also, Truebloodwolf, you can't read can you? Card clearly says creatures, not artifacts. Not sure where you were getting that in the slightest.

139509: Springleaf Drum.author: Zoah
139509: Springleaf Drum.text_parsed:
This card, in a vacuum, is probably a tad better than Paradise Mantle because of summoning sickness. You can use this on a creature that just came out. The same does not apply for Paradise mantle. You will also never have to pay it's cost again, unlike an equip cost.

If your looking to make a combo with untapping mechanics, then Paradise Mantle is cascadingly better. But if you, like me, are just trying to add speed to a deck this is the better card in many respects.

139510: Wanderer's Twig.author: Aaron_Forsythe
139510: Wanderer's Twig.text_parsed:
Aaronâs Random Card Comment of the Day #63, 2/10/11

The common any-color mana-fixer is a relatively new development. While artifact- and multicolored-themed sets certainly have always had them, it wasnât until Time Spiralâs Chromatic Star, Terramorphic Expanse, and Prismatic Lens that we started putting them into every block, sometimes multiple per set and sometimes in multiple sets in the block.

Other examples include Elsewhere Flask, Expedition Map, Shimmering Grotto, Springleaf Drum, Pilgrim's Eye, and Prophetic Prism.

The reason we make cards like these are twofold: One, we want people to be able to experiment in limited play. To do so, you might need to stretch your mana a bit, and these cards are often easy to pick up in draft if you prioritize them. Two, many of these cards are good enough mana-fixers for people whose collections donât include playsets of rare dual lands. Most notably, Terramorphic Expanse has been at or near the top of the list of most-played cards in the Casual Room on Magic Online since the card debuted.

My favorite card of this type has to be Wayfarer's Bauble from Fifth Dawn, although that card has big-time constructed ramifications so we havenât reprinted it. As for Wandererâs Twig, it did its job at the time, but I think Expedition Map is just a better-executed card from both a flavor and gameplay perspective.

To read more on my thoughts about common fixers in limited, check out my old article âThe State of Limitedâ from 2006: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af140

My favorite card of this type has to be [autocard]Wayfarer's Bauble[/autocard] from [i]Fifth Dawn[/i], although that card has big-time constructed ramifications so we havenât reprinted it. As for Wandererâs Twig, it did its job at the time, but I think [autocard]Expedition Map[/autocard] is just a better-executed card from both a flavor and gameplay perspective.

To read more on my thoughts about common fixers in limited, check out my old article âThe State of Limitedâ from 2006: http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/Article.aspx?x=mtgcom/daily/af140

139510: Wanderer's Twig.author: Cheza
139510: Wanderer's Twig.text_parsed:
@ Aaron:

As I've already said elsewhere, I am a big fan of mana acceleration/fixing for every color, since it feels natural that any color should have the same chances to play their most expensive, most iconic creature cards. But I don't really like any artifact solution, since colorless versions are less specific and therefore less flavorful than colored versions.

I am also not a big fan of multicolor strategies, since this is often used as an argument, why mono-colored solutions don't exist (see red disenchant). It should be your gameplay that leads you to a off-color cards and not the lack of in-color solutions.

So as a first step, I would make all colors be able to handle any type of permanent. Then I would distribute to each color some sort of lifegain, card advantage or mana acceleration, to increase the options in-color. You should be able to play each color either faster and war-focused or more "durable" and with a multiplayer focus.

Then, I would also include some ways to combine a color with off-color strategies to widen the overall card choices. As the last step, I would design artifacts that can be shared among any color that stabilize the previous steps. These artifacts should achieve the goal in a simple way.

For lifegain or life-acceleration, artifacts like the Demon's Horn fit quite well. For card acceleration, the old Jayemdae Tome is a good option too (also this card is far from being competetive next to a Phyrexian Arena). So mana-fixing or mana-acceleration should be done by pure mana-artifacts or card draw as well. So I don't see a real "need" for artificial land search here, since "search" doesn't really feel red at all.

In result, I don't like any of these land-search artifacts and still prefer Mana Cylix, Prophetic Prism, Coldsteel Heart, Star Compass and Darksteel Ingot.

139511: Soaring Hope.author: Nexaduro
139511: Soaring Hope.text_parsed:
Little known fact;
Long, long ago, the Orzhov conspired to invade and subjugate the plane of Lorwyn in a blatant parody of Shrek. They were met with fierce resistance; however, they held the upper hand thanks to the combined smexy of their humans and angels. All seemed lost, until the Kithkin discovered the source of their power, and one true weakness; cleavage windows. They actually devised this enchantment to rob the Ravnican invaders of this asset, and with it went on to claim total victory.
Coincidentally, that was also the end of civilian interplanar travel. Teysa had all routes shut down to preserve her reputation.

139512: Ponder.author: SleetFox
139512: Ponder.text_parsed:
The advantage Portent has is that you can sabotage opponents with it. Ponder only works on you.

So, the ups and downs of the three cards:
-Brainstorm is an instant, but only works on you and you don't get the shuffle option.
-Portent works on any player, but is a sorcery and the draw is delayed.
-Ponder lets you shuffle, but it only works on you and is a sorcery.

Also, I like this art. Not really for the merfolk but for the water effects and the whole theme of "seeing the sky through the water's surface."

139513: Howltooth Hollow.author: Mode
139513: Howltooth Hollow.text_parsed:
Heck, i can understand that this would have been quite powerful, maybe even better than the other Hideaway lands if just either condition was required, but like this that card is quite weak and rather useless...
Possibly they didn't want only you to have no cards in hand since this could make an unconditional activation of that ability possible once you empty your hand.
But since your opponent knows what this land does, he won't let you activate that ability too easy, therefore you'd have to come up with some discard in order to be able to activate it, hence i don't think this requirement alone would have been too powerful actually.

Sigh...maybe this can still find some use in a Hellbent deck or something...

139513: Howltooth Hollow.author: DarthParallax
139513: Howltooth Hollow.text_parsed:
Thou fools! You know not what you speak of!

This is BETTER in multiplayer than Duals- consider for example, the design of some card like Syphon Mind- true that one in particular would fill your hand, but in fact Discard has been severely weakened in Duels, WHILE AT THE SAME TIME they allow it to be fairly strong in Multiplayer, because they assume that people can reload/fill much, much more easily in that format- which they can.

You ask for this card to be more powerful, when I already know exactly what I want it for: Kaalia of the Vast EDH. Kaalia herself is strong enough to be repeatable, but it's difficult for her to get more than one extra free creature per turn.

Use the Hideaways for redundancy- rather than needing for them to be Engines like Kaalia, you can get fine use out of them as one-shot spells, gambles to see if you can greatly increase the pressure on a single turn. Since you don't need to control everyone's hands EVERY TURN, you will find it is much more doable to try to find the right moment to simply wipe out everyone's hand once, so that you can trigger this.

The kinds of Discard spells Wizards is willing to allow having around are exactly suited to this purpose- they do not want anyone able to easily make 'Discard LOCK' decks, but they are fine with cards like Malfegor, Syphon Mind, or other cards causing a lot of cards to be discarded, but only in a way that is usually a one-shot effect, and hard to work into an actual control strategy.

Hellbent enablers are great for Kaalia decks, because you can also Reanimate. AND you get to play Balance too. Playing all three R/B/W Hideaway Lands, plus Kaalia herself, gives you that many more chances to try to play a big creature for free.

Whenever you see a card like this and think 'this WOULD be good or great, but the cost is too much', it's usually because you are trying to put the card into the wrong deck. Sometimes, a card's dream deck hasn't yet been thought of yet. But the fact that this card forces you to think of a deck similar to the one I described, while it might seem like jumping through a lot of hoops, the result is something extremely much worth it.

There aren't really any Modern-framed cards that actually deserve this low a rating- the truth is people simply haven't yet discovered how to use them yet.

139514: Spinerock Knoll.author: DacenOctavio
139514: Spinerock Knoll.text_parsed:
@ Wraique:

Even though it's an activated ability, it still uses the word "play" in regards to the exiled card. Since you're just playing it without playing it's mana cost, you could argue that it does follow the same timing restrictions. However, comparing to how the cascade mechanic works, you could argue that such restrictions do not apply. I'll check the rules for Hideaway in the comprehensive document.

Since there is no ruling on lands with Hideaway, I suppose you could treat it like Cascade in terms of ignoring timing restrictions. However, since you're still casting the spell as a spell, it can still be countered. I wonder if Hideaway lets you play lands that you exiled while there are still objects on the stack, or if you already played a land that turn.
139514: Spinerock Knoll.text_posted:

139514: Spinerock Knoll.author: Ligerman30
139514: Spinerock Knoll.text_parsed:
I like this in my krenko, mob boss EDH more then Valikut, The Molten Pinnace due to how many non-basics I'm running. First off, you get a card filter effect which is rare in mono red and then you get you get to cheat into play Inferno Titans and massive 12/12 Battle Squadrons (Reckless One and Horde of Boggarts say hi) and btw playing Chandra Ablaze or Karn Liberated for 2 mana late game feels so good. This cycle is pretty much pure gold if you can meet it's conditions to play the spell. And the cool thing is, you don't have to trigger it yourself, if someone else deals 7 to an opponent, and you leave mana open and the knoll untapped, you can get the card out from under it w/o doing anything.

5/5 for edh, other formats ehhh, 7 damage feels a bit win more, but, you prolly have some game ending bomb in your deck worth cheating into play like in a creature heavy version of tron or maybe mosswort bridge in elves. It won't make the cut in most decks, but, it might make the cut for a few.

139515: Mosswort Bridge.author: OmegaSerris
139515: Mosswort Bridge.text_parsed:
@sonorhC
Phyrexian Dreadnought to activate the ability, not to put under the bridge.

Pay : Play Dreadnought.
In response to it's ETB trigger, pay : Activate the bridge.
Sac nothing and let the Dreadnought die.

Sure, not the most card efficient way to do it but it's quick and dirty and will get the job done for (+, if you count this tapping).

@Vampire-Elf
Shelldock Isle isn't bad if you are playing mill.

60 cards - 7 for starting hand = 53
53 - 5 for for 5 turns (you went first) = 48
Traumatize = 24 cards at the end of turn 5

That isn't counting any other milling you cause or drawing they do. But yeah, in your average control deck, the isle is pretty useless.

410, âHandling Triggered Abilities.â) Then the active player gets priority and players may play
spells and abilities. (MagicCompRules090501)

If my interpretation is correct, when you have two Merrow Commerces out, both triggered abilities will go onto the stack as the end of turn step begins. You then have priority. If everyone passes, the first item on the stack (which is the first of the two untapping triggered abilities) resolves, untapping your Merfolk. You then get priority again before the second triggered ability resolves, which means that you could potentially use activated abilities with in their cost before allowing the second untapping triggered ability to resolve.

139663: Merrow Commerce.author: Arglypuff
139663: Merrow Commerce.text_parsed:
The reason why Murkfiend Liege does not stack, as Merrow Commerce does, is because it is impossible to do anything during anybody's untap step. No player has priority, nor can any player play instants or activate abilities at instant speed during the untap step. Therefore, once the first Murkfiend Liege resolves, it is impossible to tap your creatures to have them untap with a second Murkfiend Liege.

302.2. No player receives priority during the untap step, so no spells or abilities can be played or
resolved. Any ability that triggers during this step will be held until a player would receive
priority during the upkeep step. (See rule 303, âUpkeep Step.â)

139663: Merrow Commerce.author: Aquillion
139663: Merrow Commerce.text_parsed:
@Arglypuff:

That's not why. As the section you quoted indicates, an ability that triggers during an untap phase actually waits until the next phase (normally the upkeep), and people get a chance to respond to it before it resolves then.

However, Murkfiend Liege's ability is not triggered -- it's a continuous ability (like Winter Orb) that changes the rules for the untap phase. Therefore extra copies do nothing.

If it said "At the start of each other player's untap phase..." it would be a triggered ability and would stack, with the triggered effects waiting until the untap phase and giving you a chance to respond before they resolve at that point. (Although WotC would never publish an ability that triggered during the untap phase like that, since it'd be pointlessly confusing -- it'd trigger at the start of the upkeep instead.)
139663: Merrow Commerce.text_posted:
@Arglypuff:

That's not why.  As the section you quoted indicates, an ability that triggers during an untap phase actually waits until the next phase (normally the upkeep), and people get a chance to respond to it before it resolves then.

However, [autocard]Murkfiend Liege[/autocard]'s ability is not triggered -- it's a continuous ability (like [autocard]Winter Orb[/autocard]) that changes the rules for the untap phase.  Therefore extra copies do nothing.

If it said "At the start of each other player's untap phase..." it would be a triggered ability and would stack, with the triggered effects waiting until the untap phase and giving you a chance to respond before they resolve at that point.  (Although WotC would never publish an ability that triggered during the untap phase like that, since it'd be pointlessly confusing -- it'd trigger at the start of the upkeep instead.)

139666: Galepowder Mage.author: SkaerKrow
139666: Galepowder Mage.text_parsed:
Ragamander - how?

Galepowder Mage attacks and exiles a creature. During the Second Main Phase/Post-Combat Main Phase, you tap Sundial of the Infinite to end the turn. The exiled creature never has a chance to leave exile because no Beginning of the End Step effects trigger.

This card plays well with Springjack Shepherd.

139668: Scattering Stroke.author: DarthParallax
139668: Scattering Stroke.text_parsed:
im giving this four stars. today's magic says counterspell should be 1UU, and counterspell + X should be uncommon and 2UU unless X is something stupid good. this is way better than counterspell + X, but not strictly so because of the drawback. as everyone noticed, its poorman's mana drain the way brainstorm is poor man's ancestral recall...or poor man's Jace TMS nowadays, I guess :P

@djflo: of course its situational. almost all the best cards are 'situational', but then get put into decks that tend to force that situation to come up. not having too many 'strictly better' cards keeps the game alive. i like this better than Mana Drain for that reason...and because I can afford it :P

i also like the flavor of clashing over a mana-ramp. that just seems awesome for some reason.

139670: Makeshift Mannequin.author: mkniffen
139670: Makeshift Mannequin.text_parsed: you can't raise inkwell with this. His shroud is in effect as long as he's a creature and not a spell. In your graveyard he's still a creature. The only time he isn't a creature is when he's on the stack. Thats the ONLY time he can be targeted.
139670: Makeshift Mannequin.text_posted: you can't raise inkwell with this. His shroud is in effect as long as he's a creature and not a spell. In your graveyard he's still a creature. The only time he isn't a creature is when he's on the stack. Thats the ONLY time he can be targeted.

139670: Makeshift Mannequin.author: herbomatic
139670: Makeshift Mannequin.text_parsed: Shroud only applies to permanents (that is, cards or tokens on the battlefield). In the graveyard, the Inkwell is just a creature card, and hence a valid target for reanimation.
139670: Makeshift Mannequin.text_posted: Shroud only applies to permanents (that is, cards or tokens on the battlefield). In the graveyard, the Inkwell is just a [i]creature card[/i], and hence a valid target for reanimation.

139670: Makeshift Mannequin.author: Exart
139670: Makeshift Mannequin.text_parsed:
Great for putting an Empyreal Archangel into play to buy your reanimator deck more time to find that Iona.
Or just get something that has protection from the relevant color, I tend to run one of each of Akroma, Angel of Fury, Akroma, Angel of Wrath and Sphinx of the Steel Wind.
Also the fact that it's instant allows for all kinds of funny stuff, mainly reanimations during combat or in the opponent's end step, which can easily win the game for you.
And to clarify things for mkniffen, the ONLY time Inkwell Leviathan is a creature and can't be targeted due to his shroud ability is when he's on the battlefield. In any other zone he's a creature card, except in the stack, where he's a creature spell.

Trying to figure out the timing for paying for this trigger. So by the time you pay, you already know whether you won the clash or not, right?

This seems like one of the most promising "clash triggers", but there's so few worthwhile clash cards to play with it that it seems to have turned out a dud. You want a whole lot of cards that clash, and there's only a few that are actually good.
139679: Rebellion of the Flamekin.text_posted:
Trying to figure out the timing for paying for this trigger.  So by the time you pay, you already know whether you won the clash or not, right?

139679: Rebellion of the Flamekin.author: Vinifera7

@Dragon Bloodthirsty:
When the Clash goes on the stack, this ability triggers and goes on the stack on top of the Clash. You have to choose to pay {1} before you clash.
139679: Rebellion of the Flamekin.text_posted:
@Dragon Bloodthirsty:
When the Clash goes on the stack, this ability triggers and goes on the stack on top of the Clash. You have to choose to pay {1} [i]before[/i] you clash.

139682: Silvergill Adept.author: thedarkheathen
139682: Silvergill Adept.text_parsed:
Creatures on the cheap with card advantage are awesome. When you also make them 2/1, they get even more sick. See Dark Confidant. My ideal series of plays are on the play turn 1 land Vial, turn two land Adept, counter something on their turn with a Daze, then lay down a Standstill or Lord of Atlantis and start bringing the beats.

That two power is just insane. With twelve lords in the deck, it can either be a powerhouse that bashes face, or an easy trade for something more valuable to your opponent, while you retain the card advantage off of it's cantrip.

139683: Imperious Perfect.author: Aremath
139683: Imperious Perfect.text_parsed:
Not sure how it made it down to uncommon but I'm not complaining. As EvilCleavage pointed out, still incredibly expensive despite the reprint and the rarity, so...

I feel like you would have a hard time losing a limited game with one of these out. Hard to imagine a deck with more than one.

Whenever people complain about rares being so much better than other rarities, these are the steps I take:

1. I talk about the limited format, and how it is warped by really power cards
2. I tell them about commons and uncommons (most removal and countermagic) that commonly beat rares
3. I show them this card, Vampire Nighthawk, and Standstill

Most of the time that shuts them up. I'm glad that power like this exists at uncommon.

139687: Protective Bubble.author: Atali
139687: Protective Bubble.text_parsed: Auras that provide protection to the enchanted permanent are MUCH less likely to give your opponent card advantage, since they will have to destroy the enchantment before they can destroy the permanent, rather than destroying both at once. Granted, shroud isn't the best for this, due to the vulnerability to non-targeted effects, but it means they'll have to use such an effect, and card advantage after a board wipe is usually unbalanced anyway, it might turn in your favor if you force them to use it as removal.

139687: Protective Bubble.author: OmegaSerris
139687: Protective Bubble.text_parsed:
I would love to agree with you, Atali. But the fact is, it still isn't shrouded until it resolves. The aura still can get you 2 for 1'ed with instant speed removal as does most auras. It does block the sorcery speed stuff, so it does deserve some credit, but even then, many of the sorcery speed removal spells ran are the nontargeted ones (Gatekeeper of Malakir, Wrath of God, Pyroclasm, etc...)

Hate to be the "Dies to removal" guy, but that's kind of the point of this. To protect the creature. So far, Totem Armor seems to be the best way to do this with Auras and their blatant weakness.

139687: Protective Bubble.author: Kryptnyt
139687: Protective Bubble.text_parsed:
Too expensive. Whispersilk Cloak often feels far too expensive, and that sticks around when the creature kicks the bucket. It only costs 1 more and is colorless.
The true disadvantage to an aura such as this one isn't even the card disadvantage from instant creature kill before it resolves. It's the virtual disadvantage that comes when you have no creatures to play it on, or when you're waiting for your opponent to tap out. Also, when four mana isn't increasing your damage output at all, you gotta wonder if this would even be good in draft or sealed. You'd need to clog up the board with big butts to even race slowly with it.
"Unblockable" is usually a trap when it comes to constructed anyway. People typically don't play creatures that they want to chump with. Either its bigger and will attack you back harder, or smaller and wouldn't block anyway...
Oh, one more thing. You attack with this, they kill the aura and block. Ouch.
The kind of creature you want to put this on is probably your Cephalid Constable or Raven Guild Master type of creature, I guess.

139690: Timber Protector.author: Shiny_Umbreon
139690: Timber Protector.text_parsed:
I'm surprised by the amount of people that think this is overpowered. D:

Sure, this guy would be way above the curve if it was an Elf lord or something (would still be expensive), but as a Treefolk the options for the rest of your deck are either Lorwyn treefolk (I don't think there are good ones outside the block, counting Shadowmoor) or maybe Conspiracy which is too impractical.

Want to hate Lorwyn block? Take a look at Bitterblossom or Vendilion Clique. Imperious Perfect, even Merfolk Reejerey. Those deserve it. This guy just makes a casual Treefolk deck viable, but far from overpowered.

These are the lords of indestructible:

- Avacyn, Angel of Hope (Technically not a lord, but should be mentioned)
- Frontline Medic (all though the effect is not permanent)
- Knight Exemplar (the only true lord that provides perma indestructible aside from Timber Protector)

139691: Hearthcage Giant.author: Radagast

Rather random, though technically not bad, I guess.

The numbers sort of work - a 5/5 and two 3/1's for 8. The ability at least works with itself, unlike other janky cards in this block, but the whole thing together has a clunky feel to it. It's a lot of work to just get a 5/5 that can be a 11/7 for one turn. Decent enough with Fling or similar effects, I guess.

139691: Hearthcage Giant.author: Manite
139691: Hearthcage Giant.text_parsed: One of Lorwyn's many clever cross-tribal cards. 139692: Ego Erasure.author: be-ash
139692: Ego Erasure.text_parsed:
i want to point out that this can be a brutal combat trick, in my experience when someone is attacking me i try to take their creature with mine, if i can chump block it i will but if i have to give up a creature in the process well sometimes you must, now with this i can make something look like a chump block and really turn it into a several card swing to my advantage. and thats just from the -2/-0.
now when you look at the removes tribal stuff its nice but not usually relevant to the game, but against uber tribal decks like slivers, allies, zombies, elves, or soldiers that tribal removal can do much more than -2/-0 i have used this spell to pop off numerous creatures whos p/t is equal to the number of X creature type, and remove lord bonus's to have some surprisingly effective blocks and attacks, never underestimate the power of a card like this.

139693: Neck Snap.author: EvilCleavage
139693: Neck Snap.text_parsed: This card is waaaaay underrated. It's defnintely no Path to Exile, or Swords, but this card can definitely play mind games on your opponent. Especially in a White Weenie deck that is based around early attacks getting through. Just having your opponent knowing you MIGHT have one of these in your hand can prevent him from blocking a lot of times. He doesn't want to lose that big fatty to your 2/2 kithkin or whatever. That said, this card is not bad at all. I'd recommend this one for anyone playing Lorwyn draft, or Standard, but beyond that, there are way too many other great cards that put this to shame.

139702: Merrow Reejerey.author: Iam_IronMan
139702: Merrow Reejerey.text_parsed: Maybe I'm out of my mind, but I actually don't like running this in my legacy Merfolk deck. I run Aether Vial and almost all of my other Merfolk cost 2 so I want my vials to be at 2 at all times. Having to hardcast this just makes it too slow and clunky for the build and the ability doesn't trigger off of Merfolk that are vialed in. Most of the game I won't even have 3 mana and if I do I'll usually have something more important to save it for so I often found it to be a dead card. Master of the Pearl Trident in its place lets me have my 5-8th copies of Lord of Atlantis to make my guys bigger and synergizes more with what I want to be doing.

139708: Mad Auntie.author: Misago
139708: Mad Auntie.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 4.5) Mad Auntie is a powerhouse when it comes to pumping up a goblin army. Unlike Goblin King, she grants the +1/+1 to only goblins you control. Mad Auntie's tap ability of regeneration combos very well with many other goblins. For example, I use 2 Mad Aunties in my black/red casual goblin deck to not only pump my other goblins, but to regenerate Goblin Tinkerer for continuous artifact hate. Another few cards with nice synergy are Mogg Maniac or Goblin Deathraiders. Her mana cost is also very splashable with only needing one black mana. As with other creature type leaders, do not forget to include a Goblin Matron or Boggart Harbinger to search her out. (Posted By: Misago)
139708: Mad Auntie.text_posted: (Card Rating: [b][u]4.5[/u][/b]) Mad Auntie is a [i]powerhouse[/i] when it comes to pumping up a goblin army. 139715: Knight of Meadowgrain.text_parsed:
Wow, the art truly belies the strength of this card. This cutesy knight gal on a goat (is that what it is?) is actually a beast, able to drop Goblin Piledrivers, Dimir Cutpurses and Merciless Predators like it's no big thing.

She reminds me of Hero of Bladehold. Their artworks do nothing to suggest great combat creatures, but the cards themselves are very strong and are practically must-haves in weenie decks.

139715: Knight of Meadowgrain.author: Salient
139715: Knight of Meadowgrain.text_parsed:
"If our deeds won't speak for themselves, what else could be said?"

Lots of things. Including:
"Hi!"
"How are you?"
"I ran into a Fog Bank again."
"Aww. That sucks :("
"Indeed. I has a shame."

What the flavor text fails to acknowledge is that Deeds of Meadowgrain is actually a 10/10 Kithkin Incarnation with first strike, flying, lifelink and "champion a Kithkin Knight that dealt combat advantage this turn." Now there's a Deed that can speak for itself!

139716: Wizened Cenn.author: Ferlord
139716: Wizened Cenn.text_parsed:
Here's the thing, guys: Kithkin's aren't that great.

The good Kithkin's are either Soldiers or Knights, which means that you could have constructed a better Soldier or Knight deck with them, rather than an average Kithkin deck.

Preeminent Captain - Helps Soldiers

Kinsbaile Cavalier - Helps Knights

Cenn's Tactician - Helps Soldiers

Brigid, Hero of Kinsbaile - Good low-damage boardwipey fun

Even though their lord costs 2 and is uncommon, that doesn't mean you're going to have a good time.

I know this from personal experience. A friend made a kithkin deck that loses frequently to burn, Green Ramperrun, and Zombies.

"But Zombies is a strong and expensive tribe! That's not fair!"

Yeah, and so are Soldiers and Knights.

139721: Immaculate Magistrate.author: KrosanGardener
139721: Immaculate Magistrate.text_parsed: The Onslaught elves were very reliant on tapping and having lots of themselves in play.  As a result, they never got very good.  "Oh, you play a Timberwatch elf?  That'll be a lot of trouble for me unless--oh, yup, I can just cast shock."  Compare this car with Imperious Perfect, for example, which might have a smaller effect after a few turns have passed, but immediately provides extra damage.

139726: Jagged-Scar Archers.author: Ashamed
139726: Jagged-Scar Archers.text_parsed:
Attacking and tapping to use an activated ability are two separate things. You can attack an opposing player with a creature, in order to do that you must declare you're attacking with the creature. If it does not have vigilance you tap it while declaring the attack.
The ability is used to deal damage equal to it's power to target creature with flying.

139726: Jagged-Scar Archers.author: HuntedWumpusMustDie
139726: Jagged-Scar Archers.text_parsed:
I think this is one of the best, if not the best tribe supporting creature ever printed. Cards like this, Knight exemplar, and death baron are all game closers for three mana, so long as they stay on the field. It takes all the power of Heedless One, lowers the cost, and gives it an insanely helpful ability to boot. The first ability alone makes this card a powerhouse in any elf deck, the ability to damage flying without basically any drawback seems to me to be a bit overkill. Wizards compensated for elves inability to properly deal with flying, by allowing them to handle any flying threat with ease. Originally, it seemed that elves had their weakness against flying as a way of counter-balancing their insane numbers and mana-ramping ability. I know flying-hate is the green thing to do, but decisively eliminating that characteristic (and imo necessary) weakness sort of messes with the subtle intricacies that make magic so cool.

The flavour is perfect, but I think it is just too good. I'm not even going to bother getting into the rarity haha

139727: Deathrender.author: Pantheon
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
Equip this onto a Blood Speaker!

1. On your upkeep sac the Blood Speaker to search for a Demon to put in your hand.
2. The Deathrender triggers allowing you to put that Demon onto the battlefield equiped.
3. When the Demon enters the battlefiled the Blood Speaker's retuen to hand ability triggers
4. Untap, cast the Blood Speaker again
5. Rinse and repeat.

You will get all the demons in your deck onto the battlefield in no time!

139727: Deathrender.author: Elthan
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
About the equip onto creature with shroud:

502.33a Equip is an activated ability of artifact Equipment cards. The phrase "Equip " means ": Move this Equipment onto target creature you control. Play this ability only any time you could play a sorcery."

So I believe it would be impossible to equip Inkwell Leviathan as it has shroud. This does not hinder it from being played from hand using Deathrenders ability though, as stated in the rulings.
139727: Deathrender.text_posted:
About the equip onto creature with shroud:

[i]502.33a Equip is an activated ability of artifact Equipment cards. The phrase "Equip [cost]" means "[cost]: Move this Equipment onto [b]target[/b] creature you control. Play this ability only any time you could play a sorcery."[/i]

So I believe it would be impossible to equip Inkwell Leviathan as it has shroud. This does not hinder it from being played from hand using Deathrenders ability though, as stated in the rulings.

139727: Deathrender.author: Mephastopheles
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
How about this with Blood Speaker and Lifeline? Or rather, why have a demon every turn when you can have all your demons now? :-)

(Ans: Because they'll eat each other, and your face).

Every time I read this card, it becomes more ridiculous. This and a pair of cadaver imps and a sacrifice outlet creates a potentially infinite loop that you can exploit with, amongst other things, Soul Warden effects for infinite life, Teysa, Orzhov Scion for infinite tokens, or Fecundity to draw your library. If that sacrifice outlet is Viscera Seer, it allows you to tutor a card onto the top of your library. Nantuko Husk or something similar gives you a huge creature. You could replace the Imps with Sanctum Gargoyles and put in a Disciple of the Vault for infinite damage. The possibilities are endless!

I think this has to be my favourite card!

Every time I read this card, it becomes more ridiculous. This and a pair of [autocard]cadaver imp[/autocard]s and a sacrifice outlet creates a potentially infinite loop that you can exploit with, amongst other things, [autocard]Soul Warden[/autocard] effects for infinite life, [autocard]Teysa, Orzhov Scion[/autocard] for infinite tokens, or [autocard]Fecundity[/autocard] to draw your library. If that sacrifice outlet is [autocard]Viscera Seer[/autocard], it allows you to tutor a card onto the top of your library. [autocard]Nantuko Husk[/autocard] or something similar gives you a huge creature. You could replace the Imps with [autocard]Sanctum Gargoyle[/autocard]s and put in a [autocard]Disciple of the Vault[/autocard] for infinite damage. The possibilities are endless!

I think this has to be my favourite card!

139727: Deathrender.author: Wraique
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
The word 'equipped' is ambiguous in MTG. It has two different meanings, those being 'to equip' and 'to have equipment attached'.

Inkwell Leviathan cannot be equipped by Deathrender (verb: to target with the 'equip' ability. Equip a creature).
"I payed 2 mana and tried to equip my Deathrender to my Inkwell Leviathan, but then I saw that it had shroud."

Inkwell Leviathan can be equipped by Deathrender (adjective: the state of a creature that has equipment attached to it).
"My Death Cultist had Deathrender attached to it so I sacrificed it and put Inkwell Leviathan into play, so that the leviathan came into play equipped by Deathrender."

Other examples like "Creature can't be equipped" have needed specific rulings because it could mean one of two things. Goblin Brawler for example.

Also, the ruling on this card seems to suggest that Deathrender will not attach to a permanent with pro artifacts, when indeed it will attach itself to such a permanent but then fall off as a state-based action.

139727: Deathrender.author: TheBossHammer
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
Put Ashnod's Altar on the field with a bunch of one drops, then drop Deathrender, sac the first one drop to equip Deathrender to the second. Each one drop will pay for equipping Deathrender to the next and you can empty every creature in your hand onto the field. This is viable turn 4:

Turn 1: Choice of one drop.
Turn 2: Ashnod's Altar, sac one drop -> myr of choice...maybe Iron Myr?
Turn 3: Deathrender.
Turn 4: 2 One Drops, Equip Deathrender, sac one drop -> creature of choice + Deathrender on another one drop, sac next one drop -> creature of choice + Deathrender on myr, sac myr -> creature of choice + 2 free mana, 2 free colorless -> ...Dimir Signet? :D

That's 3 free creatures on turn 4. It's unlikely to come together this fast, but it can happen.

Works great in EDH with Pathrazer of Ulamog when Thraximundar is your commander, drop a ton of stuff onto the field using the above method and leave Deathrender equipped to the last one drop when you hit 7 mana, wait for the inevitable board wipe/swing/any reason to off the guy equipped to deathrender, replace the fallen guy with Pathrazer on the opponent's turn and drop Thrax on your turn to swing for effective Annihilator 4 with a 9/9 that can only be blocked by 3+ and a 6/6 that might have just become a 10/10 on a guy that may have just pulled a boardwipe. Chances are that he won't be able to handle it. Also, obviously doesn't work against field wipes like Planar Cleansing, but at least it will force the opponent's hand and give you a good swing with Thrax.

139727: Deathrender.author: Grixxas
139727: Deathrender.text_parsed:
So here's an actual situation from a game I played with a friend that needs some more in-depth explanation...

First off, I do understand these abilities would in fact go on the stack, but I am still unsure if the abilities would trigger in the proper order to pull off this tactic.

He has on his field Creature A (his bomb card) already equipped with Deathrender, Creature B (something weak and irrelevant), Golgari Guildmage, and 5 untapped lands.
I have on my field 3 untapped lands.

- He attacks with Creature A, his bomb card
- I counter with Murder to kill it during the declare attackers step
- As soon as his Creature A hits the graveyard, he activates the first ability of the Golgari Guildmage by sacrificing Creature B to return Creature A to his hand, playing it immediately due to he triggered ability of Deathrender allowing him to play this creature from his hand pretty much upon death.

I argue that Deathrender's triggered ability to play a creature from your hand would activate before the mana ability of his Golgari Guildmage effectively rendering his tactic illegal.

Is this move legal or not? He seems to think so but I disagree. Any suggestions?

139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.author: DoctorKenneth
139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.text_parsed:
zombietomb said: "I agree that this guy is incredible, but he's such a target. Every time I play him he's either path'ed, doom bladed, bolted, or some other way removed before I can get full use of his ability. "

Here is a card.

1RR
Creature- Elemental Beast
Trample
20/3

When I play it, it gets killed before I can get in any attacks in with it. I mean, pretty much anything can take it out- Bolt, Path, Doom Blade. It's the biggest target ever. It is therefore useless.

As for our soulstroke here, I have to say that I really liked the elementals in Lorwyn. It's a little unfortunate that pretty much every tribe save Giants and Treefolk stole their thunder (though they fought back with very splashable Evokers), but it's certainly a big enough staple in other sets to deserve a lord (casual fans rejoyce!). I also like the fun things he can get up to by essentially giving all your elementals Flash (the cost reduction is the boring-yet-practical part to me). We've got enough comes-into-play effects and leaves-play-effects to make your elementals play like instants that can also block some creatures or attack while they're at it. With such a diverse group to pick through, this ability unites them surprisingly well.

Not bad at all.

139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.author: SparkleTiger
139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.text_parsed:
Incandescent Soulstoke, lovingly nicknamed "Candy" while I played a Flamekin deck when it was legal in Standard, is one of the more flavorful Lord cards Wizards has printed. You have the pump, yes, which is a staple. But you have the activated ability to shoot out Elementals at a discounted, hasty speed until the "burn out" at the end of turn. Very aligned with Red's flavor (ephemeral bursts of raw power) as well as Flamekin (passionate, fiery citizens of Lorwyn).

4.5/5 for both utility and flavor. Print more cards like this, Wizards.

139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.author: Kirbster
139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.text_parsed:
Such a great cornerstone for elementals. Use Flamekin Harbinger to fetch a Supreme Exemplar, then drop it with the Soulstoke for two mana and attack for 11 in the air. If you champion the harbinger... it'll be back at the end of the turn to grab another exemplar!

That's pretty ham-fisted play, though. In general the soulstoke gives all your guys a cheaper evoke cost and lets them get in an attack, too while they're at it. Of course, it also gives all your harbingers and smokebraiders some teeth. And who cares that you're dropping guys in the graveyard, anyway, when you can drop a hasty 5/4 Reveillark for a turn to bring them back? Though if you're really interested in keeping creatures around, just drop Maelstrom Wanderer. Two mana for an 8/6 with haste and probably two other free creatures that stick around. See if your opponent even lasts long enough for Horde of Notions to replay the wanderer out of your graveyard....

139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.author: LordRandomness
139730: Incandescent Soulstoke.text_parsed:
How have I not commented on this yet? Oh well, no matter. Nova Chaser is a nice target, but Supreme Examplar is arguably nicer in a lot of situations. There are a lot of tricks the Soulstoke is capable of, including but not limited to:

- Dropping a champion at instant speed to rescue itself or something else from removal
- Dropping a champion at instant speed in response to an evoke sacrifice, allowing the evoked creature to enter the battlefield twice and stay there
- If you have two, you can drop something with the first one and use the second to champion it
- Fourth turn Nova Chaser + Fatal Frenzy (or Rush of Blood) beat in face.
- Fling the stoked creature, because why not?
- Nevermaker tends to make people angry.
- Surprise Sunflare Shamans late game can be incredibly devastating.

139738: Thundercloud Shaman.text_parsed: This is the problem with giants in general, as a tribe they just plain yell for you to play something along side them since there really aren't that many good giant cards, especially cheap costed giant cards.  More over there's no card that says something along the lines of "add 2 mana for giant spells or activated abilities" as elementals has, which leaves us with brighthearth banneret and using warrior type.  Then we have this guy.. and it would land up killing off your own creatures/tokens.  Even your brighthearth banneret are elementals not giants.  Still, if you are sold on giants, dealing about 4 in a regular game to all is like a board wipe as long as your creatures are all giants.

139740: Herbal Poultice.author: Norin_Heir_to_Blackblade
139740: Herbal Poultice.text_parsed:
When I think of some of my favorite cards in Magic, I think of Herbal Poultice. The raw power of the card helps to accentuate its incredible synergy and beauty of design. I've seen such crazy curves as:
T1: Herbal Poultice
T2: 2 Herbal Poultices
T3: Herbal Poultice
T4: 3 Herbal Poultices!

By this time, your opponent has probably conceded.

Also, the art is possibly the finest thing I've seen since my trip to France, where I saw the Mona Lisa. The art is a subtle hint of power, with soft brown tones to represent its artifact-ness. This has been compared by some to such big hits as Black Lotus or Time Walk, and is, without a doubt, one of the most powerful magic cards in existence.

139740: Herbal Poultice.author: ClockworkSwordfish
139740: Herbal Poultice.text_parsed: Interesting difference from Welding Jar. Both costs for Welding Jar are free, but limited to artifacts. In a primarily artifact deck, Welding Jar is leagues better than this. Outside of an artifact deck, Broken Fall has the same cost-per-use and is reusable. The main usefulness of this would thus be as a free artifact for artifact decks, a context in which it is obsoleted by Welding Jar.
