139741: Scion of Oona.author: Sootoo
139741: Scion of Oona.text_parsed:
Lol @ the guys here who say this card would broken. It´s not even close to being broken. Most people who say cards would be broken, always appear to me, like total noobs who are just too retarded to find any answers to cards.

Sure, Scion of Oona is awesome with a nice army on the field, but when your opponent plays cards like Tornado Elemental, or Cloudthresher, for example, then you also already can leave the game, as long as you have no counter on hand.

However, I totally love this guy, especially when I play my Mask of Avacyn the turn before I flash him in. Since he´s only a 1/1 creature and doesn´t have shroud himself, he´s just too vulnerable, but the mask fits perfectly to him, IMO.

@Trollking
"The irony is the answers you mentioned are incredibly narrow bad answers."
I disagree that they are bad answers, but it all depends on the format you play, anyway... I am an EDH player, and there, cards like Cloudthresher (or even better the Silklash Spider for example) can be incredibly strong, especially with all the green creature tutors. If you just play a wrath, you will probably also kill your own board, anyway, while flying-hate is a perfect answer to people who play Scion of Oona, because they will most likely play flyers-only... Not to mention that not everyone can use a wrath or damnation, when they don't play the colors, but whatever...

Lol @ the guys here who say this card would broken. ItÂ´s not even close to being broken. Most people who say cards would be broken, always appear to me,  like total noobs who are just too retarded to find any answers to cards. 

Sure, Scion of Oona is awesome with a nice army on the field, but when your opponent plays cards like [autocard]Tornado Elemental[/autocard], or [autocard]Cloudthresher[/autocard], for example, then you also already can leave the game, as long as you have no counter on hand.

However, I totally love this guy, especially when I play my [autocard]Mask of Avacyn[/autocard] the turn before I flash him in. Since heÂ´s only a 1/1 creature and doesnÂ´t have shroud himself, heÂ´s just too vulnerable, but the mask fits perfectly to him, IMO.

@Trollking

140165: Sower of Temptation.author: Donovan_Fabian
140165: Sower of Temptation.text_parsed:
Keep in mind it returns a creature its taken if it dies, and its vulnerable to literally every removal spell in the game that does at least 2 from shock through lightning helix and it isn't part black.. so you can be pretty well assured it will probably eventually die. It's on par with cytoplast manipulator in that sense, but with the pro that it can be used on the spot and con that it can only be used once.

Two helpful ways to keep it alive are robe of mirrors and clout of the dominus for 5 mana total instead of 4 (4 for the creature and 1 for shroud). As mentioned above its a fun target for followed footsteps (although glen elendra archmage is probably a better one), but clone and rite of replication work just as well (as does body double, and a few other similiar cards). It's defintley a huge reveillark target.

It's best against green and even its own color blue, where removals are less and where creatures matter more (green because green is all about big creatures, and blue because its so anti creature its got to have at least something in play to win). Any other color is perfectly happy to blast it rather than let you steal their creature.

Also fun with teferi, play as an instant and steal a creature during a combat phase to make them block their own attackers.

140165: Sower of Temptation.author: typezeroserodin
140165: Sower of Temptation.text_parsed:
Scion of Oona fixes the removal problem, if you plan on playing a fae deck. Honestly this card is beautiful; my only quarrel is that this doesn't have flash...now THAT would be a devastating effect.

Another thing that's important for this card is being able to use it multiple times. Necroing it is a possibility, but that means you have no control over when it dies, which means you can't switch it by will. I suggest Mistbind Cliquefor this. What you do is you champion this card during an opponent's attack, block with Mistbind, which will hopefully die, then this card comes back into play and you get to control another creature.

140165: Sower of Temptation.author: JaxsonBateman
140165: Sower of Temptation.text_parsed:
Unlike most Mind Control cards (that is, auras), this is effectively a 3-for-1 if left unchecked.

You remove your opponent's creature - +1
You gain that creature - +1
You gain a 2/2 flier - +1 (this is the part most MCs don't get - I mean, you get an echantment, but in the case of those auras they don't do anything beyond those first 2 points, where a 2/2 flier can actually beat face)

Of course, going up to a 3-for-1 means it's more vulnerable to removal than MC, so your opponent can easily reset the balance. But at least in playing this card you provide the question, which your opponent is forced to answer - or suffer that card disadvantage.

140165: Sower of Temptation.author: seraphsembrace
140165: Sower of Temptation.text_parsed:
@JaxsonBateman

In fact, it definitely remains a +2 - you lose a card in your hand that could have been used for discard effects and gain a card on the field, leaving you with the same number of cards in total before the Sower's effect. You can argue whether or not being an Enchantment technically counts an effective -1 in advantage (although there are plenty of cards that are capable of returning or exploiting those Enchantments), but being a creature doesn't make this card into a +3. Still a good card, though.

140166: Thorn of Amethyst.author: Ferlord
140166: Thorn of Amethyst.text_parsed:
This is quite effective for hosing Storm, at least for Modern.

Although it's been through the ringer a few times, Modern storm used to rely on Pyretic Ritual, Desperate Ritual, Seething Song, and Manamorphose. You'd cast Past in Flames to do it again, and then finish off with Grapeshot. However, with this out, it effectively adds an extra + mana for the storm player to pay for.

140168: Dread.author: Japicx
140168: Dread.text_parsed:
@ Spirit of Blue

White Knight and Commander Eesha aren't exempt from Dread's ability. "Protection from X" specifically means "can't be targeted, enchanted, equipped, blocked or dealt damage by anything X", and since Dread's effect involves none of those things, protection doesn't stop Dread from killing them. You'll have to remove Dread somehow or use indestructible creatures to get around it.

Anyway, I'm generally not too attracted to black, but the sheer amount of dark power on this card is quite tempting.
140168: Dread.text_posted:
@ Spirit of Blue

White Knight and Commander Eesha aren't exempt from Dread's ability. "Protection from X" specifically means "can't be targeted, enchanted, equipped, blocked or dealt damage by anything X", and since Dread's effect involves none of those things, protection doesn't stop Dread from killing them. Anyway, I'm generally not too attracted to black, but the sheer amount of dark power on this card is quite tempting.

140168: Dread.author: Tiggurix
140168: Dread.text_parsed: @SkyKnightXi: Fear has a completely different way of functioning than intimidate. 140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: longwinded
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
@godwar, nogoodnamesleft
If you have a Goblin King in the graveyard, do your goblins get +1/+1? No. He has an ability "other goblin creatures get +1/+1," but being in the graveyard, it has no effect. Same with slivers. The Winged Sliver doesn't have flying; he has an ability "All sliver creatures have flying". Because it says "all" and not "other" he gives himself flying when his ability is in effect. His ability is not in effect while he's in the graveyard. He does not have the flying static ability. If he's the only thing in the graveyard, your Cairn Wanderer doesn't get flying.
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_posted:

140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: theis999
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
Cairn Wanderer do not gain any ability not listed on him (Flying, Fear, First Strike, Double Strike, any kind of Landwalk and Protection, Deathtouch, Trample, Haste, Shroud, Reach, Lifelink and Vigiliance). So no flanking, banding, anihilator Etc.

He does not gain any abilities while his is not on the battlefield and his does not gain any abilities of creatures not in the graveyard. Nor does he gain abilities of noncreature cards (if you should wonder).

He can not gain static abilities or parts of static abilities that isn't just those key words (works a little different for landwalk and protection, but basicly just read; has it flying or has it flying sometimes, if the latter is true then he don't get flying.), same is true for activated and triggered abilities which he will never gain. That means he doesn't gain abilities from Slivers nor from Level Up cards (unless those cards have abilities when they are level zero).

In other words: Cairn Wanderer only gains abilities from creatures in your graveyard with a very narrow set of static abilities.

So how to use him: well you can either put him in any black based tribal deck (vampires or zombies) or you can try to build around him.

If you want to build around him then using Buried Alive is a fantastic tool to do so. But which creatures to choice from?

Well, reach is not important as long as he has flying. And Flying is very common ability. First strike is not important as long as you can get double strike. Trample works good with deathtouch but is redundant with protection and landwalk, same goes for fear but that doesn't work with trample. Shroud is also redundant with protection, but it is still neat. Haste is somewhat redundant by itself. Lifelink and vigiliance is good for racing your opponent.

And here is my list of cards to use:
Thornweald Archer, Inkwell Leviathan, Spirit of the Night, Dragon Tyrant, Iridecent Angel, Horde of Notions, Giant Solifuge, Hellkite Overlord, Guardian of the Guildpact, Enemy of the Guildpact, Simic Sky Swallower, Skyhunter Skirmisher, Angelic Curator, Tel-Jilad Archers, Akroma, Angel of Wrath, Akroma, Angel of Fury, Mirran Crusader, Mirri the Cursed, Mirri, Cat Warrior, Vampire Nighthawk, Deft Duelist, Baneslayer Angel, Glissa, the Traitor, Sphinx of the Steel Wind, Wurmcoil Engine, Oversoul of Dusk and finaly Beloved Captain.

140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: Dr.Pingas
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
Most of the comments on this card disappoint me. It's a pretty clearly worded card - if it says it, it has it; and if not, don't ask. The card does not say Annihilator, Wither, Infect, ect. It gives you a pretty clear list, and if you have any decent magic experience, you should know already that you CANT ASSUME ANYTHING.
It's pretty commonly known (though I admit a little more confusing) that if an ability is conditional(if a card gains it through any means, including flipping, level-up, ect), it doesn't count, even if (in most cases) the conditions are met anyway - especially when dealing with cards in the grave, where the conditions for the abilities it lists can't be met anyway.

I hope this clears things up (again, I know) for any future comments; sorry if I got a bit ranty. All in all, he's a pretty interesting card. Best friends with Necrotic Ooze for all sorts of graveyard ability fun.

140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: WhiteWizard42
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
So, in order to make it as ridiculous as possible, you would need the following cards in graveyards:

Akroma, Angel of Wrath
Drogskol Reaver
Deadly Recluse
Shriekmaw
Inkwell Leviathan
Progenitus (It's possible to get it in the graveyard if you use Humility or Ixidron to take away its reshuffling ability before killing it)

This gives Cairn Wanderer all the useful abilities it can possibly have, since landwalk is redundant when you have protection from everything. It would even have first strike, even though it's useless with double strike.

Then drop a Concerted Effort.

(If you WANT all the landwalk abilities, you'd need to toss in a Graceful Antelope, Wrexial, Mountain Goat, Mirri, Cat Warrior, Ayumi, The Last Visitor, Dryad Sophisticate, and Zombie Musher.)

If you can think of any landwalk abilities I'm missing, or if you can think of a way to get all the non-landwalk abilities with fewer than 6 creatures, feel free to contribute.

140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: DarthParallax
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
I discovered Concerted Effort today, and I'm trying to build a Kaalia of the Vast deck with it. My first idea was to start with the Knights (Black, White, Silver, and Blood), because Kaalia is good and all, but I want a little bit of room to maneuver in case people are ready to Exile, Steal, or otherwise Kill on Sight any big uglies- the Knights 'look' less scary, but with Sword of Vengeance + Concerted Effort, they can be as awesome as the Angels, Demons, and Dragons that I'll be running as well.

So anyway, this is an odd question, but- does anyone know of any good advice for how to search Gatherer for particular kinds of cards and effects that aren't obvious? I could look up EVERY card with a keyword I wanted, but is there a faster way to try to find stuff that would be particularly good with Concerted Effort? is there a fast way to find cards with lots of keywords without typing in every combination of Keywords?

MisterAction's Theory of Fulfillment: the longer it takes to say the list of a creature's keyword abilities, the more fun you are having.

Compare: "I attack with my 20/20 unblockable."
To: "I attack with my 4/4 flying lifelink deathtouch first strike shroud islandwalk swampwalk double strike protection from black and green and colors and creatures vigilance trample haste."

140171: Cairn Wanderer.author: Chamale
140171: Cairn Wanderer.text_parsed:
If you want to play a dedicated deck with this card, try Buried Alive to bury this, Giant Solifuge, and Drogskol Reaver. Reanimate or Animate Dead for an early 4/4 with Haste, Flying, Lifelink, Double Strike, Trample, and Shroud! With Dark Ritual you can even play him on the second turn. It's not the most powerful play in a Reanimator deck, but it's fun to build your own creature.

Simply playing this in the lategame is also a good time. I love going through each player's graveyard to figure out exactly what abilities he has.

[autocard]Reanimate[/autocard] or [autocard]Animate Dead[/autocard] for an early 4/4 with Haste, Flying, Lifelink, Double Strike, Trample, and Shroud! With [autocard]Dark Ritual[/autocard] you can even play him on the second turn. It's not the most powerful play in a Reanimator deck, but it's fun to build your own creature.

Simply playing this in the lategame is also a good time. I love going through each player's graveyard to figure out exactly what abilities he has.

Since Inkwell Leviathan already gives this islandwalk replace wrexial and Mirri with Stalker hag.

Desert Nomad has a very specific landwalk ability, although it, Zombie Musher and Ayumi are unnecessary since Desert is a non basic land, and snow or legendary lands are either nonbasic or have basic types.

Doubly redundant are snow swampwalk and snow forestwalk.

140172: Sygg, River Guide.author: Justice1337
140172: Sygg, River Guide.text_parsed:
The reason he's a good EDH General is this. As per the rules, 21 damage from one commander in a single game means an opponent loses. Your commander is your best body. Also, you get to see your commander each game and it doesn't count as a card in your hand, giving you the possibility for a good mana curve every game with no cards lost. Those things considered, I see too many people playing commanders like Rubinia Soulsinger. where you don't even have a reason to cast it until someone does something. Playing high-costed, reactive commanders is not the way to go. Playing low-cost, evasive, self-protecting commanders is, like this and Skullbriar, the Walking Grave. Sygg is number two in the self-protecting department, behind Eight-and-a-Half-Tails, and he's got the benefit of being two color.

This guy was made for EDH.

(Just remember the negative synergy between Sword of Fire and Ice and Sword of Light and Shadow. Can't target... doh. You dont' want him eating a Condemn or a Spin into Myth. )

140176: Chandra Nalaar.author: Rawrzalicious
140176: Chandra Nalaar.text_parsed:
I went to my local card shop, hoping to buy a Chandra Ablaze. While he didn't have any of Ablaze, he did have Chandra Nalaar. Slightly disappointed, but still wanting a planeswalker for my burn deck, I went ahead and bought her. I went to play Magic with my friends later that day, and laid down a Quest for Pure Flame and then got it to 4 counters when I got her to 8 counters for her ultimate. My opponent healed himself to 21 life, grinning because he could kill me next turn, and I couldn't kill him on mine. I drew a Blaze, hit him for just one with it, sacced my Quest, and used Chandra's ultimate to burn him from 20 to 0 in one go.

I don't think I've ever felt more stupid about being disappointed about something. Chandra Nalaar = Best original planeswalker, hands down.

140184: Masked Admirers.author: Temple_Garden
140184: Masked Admirers.text_parsed: Seriously consider this in an elf deck. Most elf decks will have the mana spare to pull this out and it's a decent body to start beating/blocking with. The real beauty of the card comes with it's graveyard ability. If for some reason you are forced into a late game this card will push you ahead. Not only can you bring it back graveyard and cast it again, but it will draw you another card. I will often use this to attack late game even when I know it will die achieving nothing, just so I can bring it back and draw an extra card. This card is very powerful card advantage when you have the mana and a decent powered elf when it's in play.

140184: Masked Admirers.author: Mode
140184: Masked Admirers.text_parsed:
I'm still puzzled by the fact that this is a 'group creature' that doesn't have a P/T that's equal to the amount of creatures seen in the art (so each of them would represent a 1/1 Elf).
Maybe the one who bows down in the middle symbolizes that he gets caught off-guard, so we're only left with two toughness from the other elves to his left and his right? Does this make sense?

About the card itself, i'd say it's really reliable. Getting a 3/2 cantrip for four mana is alright, especially if you can easily return him from your graveyard the next time you pay an extra two mana with the next creature you cast (which, again, kind of works like a cantrip). The creature types are also useful.
It bugs me a bit that it requires and not , but Wizards probably didn't want decks to benefit from that card without running green.

They would make a great pick in limited.

@fabujs: As long as the 2 CMC spell doesn't say "cast" that your 4 CMC spell for free, then you can get around Gaddock Teeg. 140188: Gaddock Teeg.author: Guest513736147
140188: Gaddock Teeg.text_parsed:
I think most people seem to be misunderstanding what a control deck is supposed to do. Gaddock Teeg screams to me "I stop Wrath of God!". Who wants to stop Wrath of God? Not control.

Aggro.

Aggro doesn't want Wraths, or Force of Wills, or Dragonstorms, or Cryptic Commands to be played. Aggro wants to keep its horde of cheap creatures alive, and that seems like what this card is for. And what it has been used for in the past, particularly during Lorwyn Standard when Kithkin was one of the most powerful archetypes. Kithkin is not a control deck, folks.
140188: Gaddock Teeg.text_posted:
I think most people seem to be misunderstanding what a control deck is supposed to do. Gaddock Teeg screams to me "I stop [autocard]Wrath of God[/autocard]!". Who wants to stop Wrath of God? Not control.

Aggro.

Aggro doesn't want Wraths, or [autocard]Force of Will[/autocard]s, or [autocard]Dragonstorm[/autocard]s, or [autocard]Cryptic Command[/autocard]s to be played. Aggro wants to keep its horde of cheap creatures alive, and that seems like what this card is for. And what it has been used for in the past, particularly during Lorwyn Standard when Kithkin was one of the most powerful archetypes. Kithkin is not a control deck, folks.

140188: Gaddock Teeg.author: JohnnyBoi
140188: Gaddock Teeg.text_parsed:
@guest1334148255:
You couldn't use medallions to get around his restriction, neither can you use, say Thorn of Amethyst to mess further with your opponents. This is because those effects doesn't change the CMC, they're modifying it - an effect that comes into play in addition to the CMC. When you cast a spell, the cost is calculated by first taking the CMC, then adding any present modifiers.
Thing is, I got both Gaddock and Thorn of Amethyst on the same day in two different Lorwyn packs, and I immediately thought of that combo, but wanted to look it up thoroughly in the rules first...was a bit dissapointed when I found out what I just explained... ;)

140188: Gaddock Teeg.author: bowlofgumbo
140188: Gaddock Teeg.text_parsed:
The Teeg's legitimacy as an EDH general is three pronged:

(1) He's multicolored.
(2) He's cheap, so you can reliably get him in play quickly, and reasonably continue to replay him when he becomes the target of hate.
(3) Since EDH is a format that actually encourages higher-cost spells in general, his abilities are more effective than in a standard game-play setting.

140190: Guile.author: raptorman333
140190: Guile.text_parsed:
I had thought this over for the longest time and came to this determination based on the following self-inquiry:

Q: If a spell targets one of my creatures in play (e.g. a kicked Into the Roil)and I either give that creature shroud/hexproof or remove the creature from play, the spell is countered? Does that mean I get to spelljack it with Guile?

The answer I came up with: No, because the spell wasn't countered by a spell or ability that I controlled, but, rather, by the absence of a legal target. Ergo, the ruling, "Guile's second ability replaces "counter " with "exile and you may cast it without paying its mana cost."
140190: Guile.text_posted:
I had thought this over for the longest time and came to this determination based on the following self-inquiry:

Q: If a spell targets one of my creatures in play (e.g. a kicked [autocard]Into the Roil[/autocard])and I either give that creature shroud/hexproof or remove the creature from play, the spell is countered?  Does that mean I get to [autocard]spelljack[/autocard] it with Guile?

The answer I came up with:  No, because the spell wasn't countered by a spell or ability that I controlled, but, rather, by the absence of a legal target.  Ergo, the ruling, "Guile's second ability replaces "counter [a certain spell]" with "exile [a certain spell] and you may cast it without paying its mana cost."

140193: Militia's Pride.author: Bobmacambob
140193: Militia's Pride.text_parsed:
WHAT?!?!?!??! NOT AS GOOD AS BITTERBLOSSOM?!?!?!?!?!?!

Oh right... wait:
@ Vorthosian

WHAT?!?!?!??! NOT AS GOOD AS BITTERBLOSSOM?!?!?!?!?!?!
This card... IS ... OWNAGE....

Ok, so with Bitterblossom, you pay one life at each upkeep to get one token.
With Militia's Pride you pay one mana for each attacking creature. And it's technically got haste. Ok, you don't get the option to use it as a chump-blocker but you DO get potential multiple attackers.

In a proper Kithkin deck, these little 1/1s become pretty significant threats.

One small thing is that this can also be played OUTSIDE a Kithkin deck. You could make it a mana-ramp deck (I don't now how but that would be an interesting deck to see... maybe some kind of color changing thing? nah ok, not mana ramp)

It would be interesting in a SOLDIER deck.

Just notice that it doesn't say "nontoken KITHKIN creature..." but "nontoken creature..." which is pretty interesting...

Last thing is that Bitterblossom puts its owner on a time-bomb. Ok, Faeries are FAST but Bitterblossom is only REALLY REALLY good (as far as i know) BECAUSE there are lots of other OWNAGE Faeries around...

Oh, and I've played with Militia's Pride but not BITTERBLOSSOM but that's what I think anyways... :P

140200: Shapesharer.author: ProbablyThatGuy
140200: Shapesharer.text_parsed: I shied away from this guy at first, since it cost a decent bit to activate his ability, and it only lasts a single turn. I was wrong to underestimate him like that though. His true strength is realized in multiplayer, where you have a wide variety of options to chose from, which he can become a copy of at instant speed, as you need it. Not an efficient offensive threat generally, but a very strong reactive control piece with stronger utility as your opponents play stronger things. His main downside is that he will already be chilling on the board before you can use his copy ability (unless you pull off some kind of flash combo or whatever), so your opponent has the opportunity to work around him if they are able. He deserves his current 4/5 in my opinion.

140200: Shapesharer.author: BG-Hunter
140200: Shapesharer.text_parsed:
So many people underestimated this guy... He shine especially in multiplayer games. Some of the cards I have tried with him, which proved to be a huge success, would be Vigor, Nacatl War-Pride, Fathom Mage, Master Biomancer, Biovisionary (this combo is really troll) Giant Adephage. There are tons of great combo's with him.

The problem is to get the mana needed for the somewhat costly effect - some solutions, which have been mentioned, is to use him in an elemental deck along with Smokebraider + Nova Chaser and Flamekin Harbinger. The activated ability from Smokebraider allows for cheap usage of his copy ability.

He could likewise mesh well with cards such as Hamletback Goliath since he would gain x+1/+1 counters as well when a creature enters the battlefield - these counters wont leave once he return to his normal shape at the next turn! This is also why I believe he fill in extremely well in a Simic deck which features cards such as Vigor + Gyre Sage + Fathom Mage + Master Biomancer (currently playtesting such deck which also features the infamous Nacatl War-Pride) - my reasoning behind this is that once he gain counters he can be transformed into various Simic sources such as the cards that allow for more mana, card draw, protection and offensive moves - Gyre Sage especially makes it somewhat easy to use his ability since the G mana gained from the card can fill in as the collourless payment.

I encourage you all to try grab one of these fellows in a deck that features U combined with any other colour since he allow for some cool plays! :)

140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: SleetFox
140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
Everyone knows Doran is a great card, but there's a fun fact that not many people know.

Doran is the only wedge-colored card that's not part of a cycle. There are only 11 wedge cards. There are 5 from the Apocalypse cycle (which is where Lightning Angel is from), there are the 5 wedge dragons from Planar Chaos, and then there's Doran.

This is, of course, not counting honorary wedge cards such as single-colored cards that have activated abilities that cost enemy mana.

@Sarroth Actually, it would make Force of Savagery a 0/0; In your example, you switched its power and toughness, which is not what Doran does. Now, obviously you do need something else in play to keep the force alive to begin with, so at minimum it would become a 1/1 in combat.

Now, obviously you do need something else in play to keep the force alive to begin with, so at minimum it would become a 1/1 in combat.

140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_posted: [autocard]Force of Savagery[/autocard] is an 8/0 with or without Doran in play. He would deal 0 damage with Doran in play (if he could live with 0 toughness)

140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: sarroth
140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
@Colossus_of_darkstee: Doran won't save Force of Savagery: Doran doesn't switch P/T, he only changes how damage is designed. Force doesn't become a 0/8; it is still an 8/0 and will die without Glorious Anthem or other such effect. (@endersblade: Reread my post - I said Doran doesn't switch P/T).

@Robram: Sometimes cards are just too good for one or two colors, so they throw in a third to make it fair. Many of the 3-colored dragons fit this. He is no less black than blue or red, but I can see how R&D would think him as {1}{G}{W}, or even {2}{G}{W} is too good. It's not necessarily a problem with wedge colors, but a problem with balancing out powers over eas-ability to cast. Yes I just made up a word.

I love Doran, but he's so popular as a Commander card, which makes me hesitant to jump on that bandwagon. I agree with everyone asking for a Wedge block, though. And yes, the Commander precons have wedge decks, but they don't count. There isn't a storyline and flavor like with the shards in Alara block, and it's the flavor of the shards that makes me want to play their colors, not just the cards they get.

140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: Morgrath
140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
The treefolk in Lorwyn/Shadowmoor were GWB because those are the colours that fit. Green is obvious, they're trees, growth etc. Black and green actually have a fairly large philosophical alignment when it comes to the circle of life stuff. If anything, white is the colour that least fit with them, but I suppose there was a lot of defender/protector flavour surrounding them, so that gets white in.

It's pointless to say that a card like this, multi-coloured but with one ability, doesn't fit one of its colours. It'd be like saying one of the Nephilim doesn't fit in one of it's colours. Doran's ability and colours are based on his (and his race's) flavour, not each other.

140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.author: blurrymadness
140201: Doran, the Siege Tower.text_parsed:
I'm going to be a little different and point out a cool application for him in Legacy:
-He attacks through Ensnaring Bridge

That should be all you need, but there's more depending on your deck-building:
-He buffs Tarmogoyfs slightly
-He buffs Deathrite Shaman to a 2/2 on his already ridiculous body
-He's fetchable via Green Sun's Zenith
-Other random good creatures like Courser of Kruphix

So he's a 3-mana Bramble Creeper who you can protect with Karakas. Keep him in the sideboard as helping your GB opponents or getting bounced by Karakas is annoying as well as 0-Life Plows; but against your blue/black fair-deck opponents bring him in. He makes Snapcaster, Dark Confidant, True-Name Nemesis, and other lopsided creatures hit for a measly 1 while being a 5/5 T3. And again, being able to bounce him to Karakas allows for infinite blocks and hard to remove while being a never ending threat.

As a 1-of; he's hard to pass up just for the Ensnaring Bridge effect; and honestly; who doesn't like whipping out crazy Legendary creatures in legacy!?

Notably being green, you have atleast 2-3 fairly large dudes on the board ATLEAST by the time you play garruk. 140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.author: Queen_of_the_Fae
140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.text_parsed:
He is a powerhouse. 'Nuff said. One of the most powerful 'walkers they have printed.

His first ability means that he basically costs two. Which plays well with green, because he can protect himself by allowing you to play him and a creature for blocking in the same turn.

His second ability is used occasionally, from what I've seen, and is always good. A free 3/3? and it only delays his ultimate overrun one turn with its cost of -1!

His last ability . . . has there really been anything more iconically green than Overrun? And only a 1 turn wait before Garruk can activate it? There really is nothing more to say about this elegant speedy green effect.

The first green Planeswalker. And so-far the only mono-green one. But unlike most 'walker's abilities . . . his "build-up" ability and his "ultimate" ability have only a slight side synergy with each other. (He untaps lands that allows for a player to play more creatures that then get buffed by the overrun . . . but that is not always the case, and doesn't directly bolster his ultimate's effect.)

He is still an insanely good card!

140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.author: orisiti
140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.text_parsed: I don't think people are seeing how he fits in his niche... if played right, he will survive to do quite a bit.  He belongs in creature decks, and therefore should have blockers already out. The final isn't (always) game ending because they also made it cheap enough to easily replicate. Mixed with overgrowth or other mana producing enchant lands, his first ability can make a big green deck explode off the line, his 2nd ability can keep you and him alive in the slow first steps of a large creature or sap deck, and his 3rd works equally well in either of these decks as well.  In a big green deck, it gives you creatures the trample they need to use their awesome power (and a little extra power to boot), or in a sap deck it makes you horde of little guys four times as powerful... getting 5 saps past gets you 20 damage, plus any extra from small blockers getting trampled. Lastley, if you waited to overrun till the moment was right, then you are probably close to doing it again, or have a couple of extra stampeders when it goes off.

140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.author: blurrymadness
140205: Garruk Wildspeaker.text_parsed:
3 3/3s for 4 mana is pretty good; even over 3 turns; but usually you'll:
-Drop a beast now, ramp next turn into something 6-7 cost
-Ramp now, getting a 2-3 drop out
-Ramp now pointlessly because you're going to use him as a ticking overrun

He's always useful either by gaining board position, mana-fixing, ramping into a finisher, comboing, or whatever else. Fun and fantastic with Lotus Cobra; also, ~$5; which isn't bad for a decent walker that will probably get reprinted.

140212: Liliana Vess.author: Asinine-Ultimatum
140212: Liliana Vess.text_parsed: People seem to be terribly harsh to Lilliana Vess so I feel I should offer an alternative view! I've found various good uses for her. I tend to use her first ability as another way to help Vulturous Zombie on its way to being gigantic. I agree with the view that her tutor ability is somewhat frustrating as you usually have to wait till your next draw for you card but a tutor is a tutor nonetheless and I'm not going to complain at a repeatable one! Yes, I know, her final ability is virtually never going to happen but I've made it happen once and it put a f***ing big smile on my face when it did! So don't be a tournament snob and berate her because she's not going to win you any top-prizes; she's fun and nasty in a casual environment and that's good enough for me!

140212: Liliana Vess.author: Queen_of_the_Fae
140212: Liliana Vess.text_parsed:
I have to agree with Asinine-Ultimatum. (How funny it is to agree with someone who is "asinine".^_^)

A very decent first ability! I can't fathom why people seem to think that this is bad? Yes she does cost 5 to bring out . . . and 5cc for discard 1 card does suck (if that is the only thing that spell does) . . . but at that point in the game (in an aggressive format, or if your thing is discard) they don't have many cards in their hand . . . and a continual -1 to their hand is vicious when supported with other cards.

Her second ability is nice. A continual tutor effect!? (Yes it would be better as an instant, but isn't everything better as an instant?) Black tutors stuff. It's what it does. And her continual tutor can give you just what you need when you need it. (And isn't it really similar to Diabolic Tutor because you often don't play the card you tutor up that turn?)

Her last ability... A game winner. Right then and there. When it goes off it says: YOU. WILL. WIN. THIS. GAME. (Unless they can prevent all the damage that you are about to do next turn.) There really is very little any of the colors can do (save white) to stop the effects of her ultimate ability after it goes off. (Aside from winning the game that turn . . . RED)

A great black start to begin this new card type. And like most 'walker's abilities . . . her "build-up" ability and her "ultimate" ability have awesome synergy with each other. (Discarding creatures into a graveyard . . . only to be reanimated into a huge army under your control poised to kill your opponent!)

140212: Liliana Vess.author: stygimoloch
140212: Liliana Vess.text_parsed:
I'm not a massive fan of any of the planeswalkers, but I downright dislike the Villainess. I have literally not once seen her justify her mana cost or deck slot. In my experience she just doesn't work out in play as anything other than a not-tremendously-efficient tutor.

@ Asinine-Ultimatum: I do feel the need to point out that I'm not a tournament player, and in fact quit playing in tournaments over five years ago. I've only seen her final ability go off a handful of times in casual play, and even then, you really need either a deck dedicated to abusing the ability or to be playing in a large multiplayer game, otherwise it's still not as big a deal as it feels like it ought to be. Very few of the Planeswalkers actually make that much of a difference on the board in my experience, but if you can get their ultimate off, that's usually a huge deal. Liliana's has never really worked out in games I've played or watched. Be it a board sweeper, or the opponent having enough defenders to absorb it, or there just not being that many creatures in graveyards anyway, it's never really proved pivotal the way Chandra, Ajani or Garruk's final abilities have. That said I admire the design touch that as the ability gets better (the longer the game goes/the more players there are), the easier it becomes to deal with it. That's well-balanced imo.

@ Queen-of-the-Fae: Obviously I disagree with you statement about the final ability being a game-winner (see above), but I guess we just have different experiences of her. But as for her first ability, I don't think it's bad, I just know I can get better repeatable effects for five mana. Taken as an overall package, I've just never seen her do anything other cards couldn't do more effectively.
140212: Liliana Vess.text_posted:
I'm not a massive fan of any of the planeswalkers, but I downright dislike the Villainess. I have literally not once seen her justify her mana cost or deck slot. In my experience she just doesn't work out in play as anything other than a not-tremendously-efficient tutor.

@ Asinine-Ultimatum: I do feel the need to point out that I'm not a tournament player, and in fact quit playing in tournaments over five years ago. I've only seen her final ability go off a handful of times in casual play, and even then, you really need either a deck dedicated to abusing the ability or to be playing in a large multiplayer game, otherwise it's still not as big a deal as it feels like it ought to be. Very few of the Planeswalkers actually make that much of a difference on the board in my experience, but if you [i]can[/i] get their ultimate off, that's usually a huge deal. Liliana's has never really worked out in games I've played or watched. Be it a board sweeper, or the opponent having enough defenders to absorb it, or there just not being that many creatures in graveyards anyway, it's never really proved pivotal the way Chandra, Ajani or Garruk's final abilities have. That said I admire the design touch that as the ability gets better (the longer the game goes/the more players there are), the easier it becomes to deal with it. That's well-balanced imo.

@ Queen-of-the-Fae: Obviously I disagree with you statement about the final ability being a game-winner (see above), but I guess we just have different experiences of her. But as for her first ability, I don't think it's [i]bad[/i], I just know I can get better repeatable effects for five mana. Taken as an overall package, I've just never seen her do anything other cards couldn't do more effectively.

140214: Purity.author: Vinifera7
140214: Purity.text_parsed:
@Donovan_Fabian:
As far as I am aware, life loss caused by Sanguine Bond, et al., is not damage. For something to be considered damage, it must actually have the word "damage" written.

To summarize, damage causes loss of life, but loss of life is not necessarily caused by damage.

140214: Purity.author: Lege
140214: Purity.text_parsed:
Here's a raw version of a hilarious combo decklist:

4 Purity
4 Pestilence
4 Souls of the Faultless
4 Sanguine Bond
4 Mana Tithe
4 Diabolic Tutor
4 Dark Ritual
2 Enlightened Tutor
2 Boon Reflection
4 Open slots (Terror? Sign in Blood? Indestructibility? Blockers? Up to you)

24 Land

The basic gist behind this deck is using your main card, Pestilence, in combination with Purity to deal yourself and the Souls damage so you gain life and your opponent loses it. Tutors help you find the cards you need and mana tithe gives you control. Souls of the Faultless can be replaced for other control cards, Boon Reflections can be replaced for another 2 Enlightened Tutors, and you can easily transform this deck into a legacy control deck by reducing some of the cards into singletons and putting in more counterspells and tutors.

140216: Rings of Brighthearth.author: Mode
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_parsed:
This card is great with so many cards. Planeswalkers in particular,
but copying strong abilities from permanents with tough cost (which require saccing or similar) are often also very effective.
Fetchlands for instance are a great thing as well since it gives you an additional land for (or only after tapping the second fetched land) without card disadvantage.
Magosi, the Waterveil also does a good job since this card allows additional turns despite all the restrictions it has. Use with Garruk Wildspeaker to circumvent being forced to skip a turn at first and get an infinite amount of turns immediately.

140216: Rings of Brighthearth.author: Magnor_Criol
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_parsed:
Haha, Door to Nothingness - "You lose so hard, you lose twice." Style points in a duel, actually practical in multiplayer.

How is this not rated higher? This thing is bonkers. So many activated abilities that are so very, very excellent when doubled - especially since, as it's been pointed out, when you copy it you don't have to pay additional costs. Planeswalker abilities, people. This is one of the very few cards that will let you abuse planeswalkers.

Sorin Markov - Control your opponent's next two turns.
Venser, the Sojourner - Exile two permanents with each spell you cast. (Warning: Could get dangerous for you, since it's mandatory)
Koth of the Hammer - Add RR to your mana pool for each mountain to superpower an X spell.
Gideon Jura - Destroy two creatures. (Not as flashy as the others, but still brutal.)
Elspeth Tirel - Putting six creature tokens on the field at once is an incredibly - and deceptively - strong way to impact the board.

140216: Rings of Brighthearth.author: Ava_Adore
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_parsed:
This is one of those cards that are hard to use without completely breaking the game, reminds me of freed from the reel.

Best use is for sacrifice abilities, as the sacrifice is part of the cost you can get twice the effect for just a lil bit of mana.

its even better with legendary creatures as you can effectively have two of them out in play if its sole use is a tap ability, Arcum anyone?

Also gives multicolored decks a mana sink for intensive spell costs,

also if an ability has x in its cost you can copy that value for 2 mana, making you effectively save a heap of mana on blaze like abilities. e.g. Flameblast Dragon's ability

if you pay 4R for its blaze for an extra 2 mana with this you can deal another 4 damage and save yourself 4 mana, and it will let you target a new player/creature

140216: Rings of Brighthearth.author: strider24seven
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_parsed:
@ Slagoon
No, you cannot normally use a single Rings of Brighthearth to copy any activated more than once. It is a triggered ability which is put on the stack whenever you use an activated ability. You can either pay the mana for Rings once or not at all, which will either get you one copy or no copies. If you had more than one copy of Rings, though, you would get more than one trigger.

@DarthParallax
Kaalia of the Vast's ability doesn't work with Rings. Her ability is a triggered ability that goes on the stack when she attacks. Rings only works on activated abilities.

@Averyck
The stack will look like this:
--RIngs Trigger
--Rhys the Redeemed's 2nd ability

Rings trigger resolves putting a copy of every token you control into play (2x original # of tokens).
Rhys ability resolves puttinga copy of every token you control into play (4x original # of tokens).

Rings only cares if the ability is activated- targeting is irrelevant.
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_posted:
@ Slagoon
No, you cannot normally use a single [c]Rings of Brighthearth[/c] to copy any activated more than once.  It is a triggered ability which is put on the stack whenever you use an activated ability.  You can either pay the mana for Rings once or not at all, which will either get you one copy or no copies.  If you had more than one copy of Rings, though, you would get more than one trigger.

@DarthParallax
[c]Kaalia of the Vast[/c]'s ability doesn't work with Rings.  Her ability is a triggered ability that goes on the stack when she attacks.  Rings only works on activated abilities.

@Averyck
The stack will look like this:
--RIngs Trigger
--[c]Rhys the Redeemed[/c]'s 2nd ability

Rings trigger resolves putting a copy of every token you control into play (2x original # of tokens).
Rhys ability resolves puttinga copy of every token you control into play (4x original # of tokens).

Rings only cares if the ability is activated- targeting is irrelevant.

140216: Rings of Brighthearth.author: JaxsonBateman
140216: Rings of Brighthearth.text_parsed:
Quite a good card that can be used in a variety of decks. Personally, I've been having some success with in in a casual esper artifacts deck - it works well alongside quite a few artifacts, but in particular Kuldotha Forgemaster (saccing 3 arts for repeatable tinker is already good enough, but double tinkering is just silly).

I had this incident come up in my latest game:

I'm playing the esper artifacts against a black/green sacrifice sort of deck. He swept my awesome boardstate of 2 Mother of Runes, a Baleful Strix and a Master Transmuter, so I'm not doing well. On turn 5 I play my fifth land and Kuldotha Forgemaster. On his turn 5 he hits me with an Abyssal Persecutor backed up by 2 Homicidal Seclusion, for a massive hit. Post combat he plays Demonic Taskmaster, so I know I'm dead next turn unless I can kill a creature (or both for safety), or win. Fortunately he's tapped out, so I know that the ball is almost certainly entirely in my court.

On my turn 6 I play my sixth land and a Time Sieve. My boardstate is 6 lands (including 3 artifact lands), Rings of Brighthearth, Time Sieve and Kuldotha Forgemaster. I tap the 3 art lands for mana, floating WUB, and sacrifice them to activate Forgemaster. I copy Forgemaster's ability with the Rings, so I only have U floating. With my first fetch, I grab a Myr Battlesphere. With the second fetch still on the stack, I activate Time Sieve, sacrificing the Battlesphere and Myr tokens, and copy the ability with the Rings, so 2 extra turns await me. I then let the other fetch resolve and get out Sharuum, fishing me out my just-sacrificed Battlesphere. I then start my next turn.

On my first extra turn, I sac 3 of the Myr tokens I created thanks to Sharuum fetching Battlesphere, and I copy the ability with the Rings. With my first search I get out Blightsteel Colossus, and with my second search I get out Spine of Ish Sah to destroy his Taskmaster, his only creature capable of blocking. And of course, that yielded the concession as he knew the only way he could win is if I forgot to attack on my final extra turn.

140217: Brion Stoutarm.author: Donovan_Fabian
140217: Brion Stoutarm.text_parsed: There are several good ways to use this creature, if for no other reason than he's only 4 mana for a lifelink creature, but that second ability is very interesting.  Yes you have to sacrifice a creature, but you could use token, or you could use dominus of fealty or sarkahn vol to take your opponents creatures to whack them with.  Primarily what makes the ability so attractive is actually the amount of combat tricks you can play with it.  Imagine you sneak a token past your opponents defenses, play a colossal might on it to do 5, then sacrifice it to do another 5, for a total of 10.  You could also put a devour creature into play, devour everything else for a huge creature, then throw it at your opponent for an immediate game finisher.  If one of your creatures has first strike, it can also do damage, then be sacrificed to do all its damage a second time.  Admittedly your not going to want to sacrifice creatures left and right unless you have a steady supply of tokens, but if your creature is about to die anyways, or be removed by a spell, then may as well get some more damage in.  Can also save your creatures from exiling, if its about to be exiled you can sacrifice it to do damage, and then at least you can revive it later.  A synergistic devour combo might be goblin assault enchantment, then voracious dragon which deals damage based on the amount of goblins it eats when it comes into play, then sacrifice it with brion to do some major damage.

140217: Brion Stoutarm.author: dr_murk
140217: Brion Stoutarm.text_parsed:
Here's a pretty nifty combo:

1) Get Brion out
2) Get Mirror Entity out, along with any other creature.
3) Equip Deathrender to the third creature.
4) Spend mana to make the other creature as strong as you can (it also has +2/+2 due to the Deathrende)r.
5) Sacrifice creature and send down another one due to Deathrender.

Repeat for a few turn.

(Sorry for the double post, other one got messed up.)

140222: Jace Beleren.author: MetalCrisis
140222: Jace Beleren.text_parsed:
I really like this guy. At worst, he's a Howling Mine, and at best he's a Phyrexian Arena. I don't think you'll use his final ability that much unless you have a milling deck, but his first two abilities are reason enough to play him.

Jace's one drawback is that he has no way to defend himself. You'll find that he takes a lot of damage because can't spit out tokens every turn to block for him like Elsepth and Garruk do.

140222: Jace Beleren.author: BrimandVormay
140222: Jace Beleren.text_parsed: even if you're not in a milling deck, jace has the focus to allow you to make an opponent discard 40 cards in 9 turns, combined with the fact that they have 9 extra cards almost 50 cards in there deck would have been used already. the best part is that even though your opponent might have 9 extra cards if you want to hold off on his effect for an extra turn you can have 11 extra cards at your disposal... not too shabby. all in all this guy is a bamf, he's in my opinion one of the top 3 planeswalkers. i do however think that elspeth (precious invincibility for all your cards) and lithiana (all the creatures in the graveyard come into play under your control) still have him for final effects though.

140222: Jace Beleren.author: True_Mumin

Jace is very good, although he might not seem like much compared to other Planeswalkers. What I REALLY love about him, though, is the illustration. His design is astonishing, so menacing... He just radiates power. A frightening power, I might add. The barren background also plays a role here. In my eyes, other Planeswalkers look more like mere legends when compared to him. I consider Jace to be one of the characters with the best design, not just in Magic, but in general.

Oh, and take a look at THIS:

http://www.coolstuffinc.com/images/Products/mtg%20art/Promo/book-jace-beleren.jpg

That's just epic. Kudos to Aleksi Briclot.

He just radiates power. A frightening power, I might add. The barren background also plays a role here. In my eyes, other Planeswalkers look more like mere legends when compared to him. I consider Jace to be one of the characters with the best design, not just in Magic, but in general.

Oh, and take a look at THIS:

http://www.coolstuffinc.com/images/Products/mtg%20art/Promo/book-jace-beleren.jpg

That's just epic. Kudos to Aleksi Briclot.

I think Jace is my favorite planeswalker.

140226: Wort, Boggart Auntie.author: Misago
140226: Wort, Boggart Auntie.text_parsed: (Card Rating: 5.0) This card wins games by providing a nasty card advantage for goblin decks. Since she is legendary, having more than one in hand can be a dead card. Henceforth, I run only one of her in my casual black/red goblin deck. I also run 4 Goblin Matron to search her out as soon as possible. To ensure her safety, I include 2 Goblin Chirurgeon and 2 Mad Auntie. When all is lost and she ends up in my graveyard, I put her on top of my deck with Volrath's Stronghold. Even without goblins in your graveyard, she is still a relevant threat with a 3/3 body and fear. Honestly one of the best goblins in MTG. (Posted By: Misago)

140226: Wort, Boggart Auntie.author: Nip_Gwyllion
140226: Wort, Boggart Auntie.text_parsed:
@KingXerxes

How does that deck even work? Wort doesn't seem to fit anywhere in there, and all the invokers seem useless, being too reliant on you drawing a Training Grounds, and even then, you'd need two or three in order for the mana cost of their abilities to be low enough that they'd keep up with even the worst of casual decks you'd find... Hunted Phantasm seems completely out of place. You don't get the goblins, your opponent does. And while that's helpful for Gempalm Incinerator, the incinerator only hits creatures and you're only playing two of them. If you really want to make a deck based around Wort, you should put in things that actually work with her: goblins that frequently hit the graveyard.

We all know Wort is good with Tarfire and Nameless Inversion, but there are other things that would work well in the deck. Goblin Grenade is a one-cost 5-damage spell, at the cost of losing a single Goblin, which Wort will just bring right back. Skirk Prospector is good as well, because you can sacrifice Goblins for extra mana, and bring them right back with Wort on the very next turn. And since we're using Skirk Prospector, it's a good idea to also use Ib Halfheart. If the game goes on too long, you can just tap all your lands, sacrifice them to Ib to turn them into Goblins, then sacrifice all of those to use whatever x-cost burn spell you choose. If you've been playing goblins throughout the whole game, you can easily drop a 14 or 15-damage Fireball on your opponents on turn five or six.

It was an OK idea, but it just doesn't seem all that plausible that you'll win with the deck.

140227: Vigor.author: Donovan_Fabian
140227: Vigor.text_parsed: For all the posters saying hey you could get a 30 power saproling.. look at that card again.  Unless you have multiple vigors in play, it doesn't prevent damage to itself.  That means if your opponent simply burns your vigor off the field, it doesn't do anything.  Its only functional with other cards in play.  Your opponent can still attack/block/destroy vigor, or use destroy on your other creatures, because destroy effects are not damage.  That leaves a big gaping hole in the defense strategy with this card.  On the other hand, vigor is still a great token protector, and a large bodied trampler.  Finding a way to give it any type of shroud, or play a clone or followed footsteps to get multiples of it might end the game though it would take time.  In some ways its better to get a creature thats going to end the game for you vs. hopefully buffing up a few of your other creatures, its about risk vs. reward, and have to remember that when trying to play vigor.  Personally, I like meglonoth as my 6 mana slot for a trampler, its huge, and has vigilance, and a blocking effect.

140227: Vigor.author: JaxsonBateman
140227: Vigor.text_parsed:
It's cards like this which remind players just why targetted spot removal is so damn important these days. Case in point - a standard vamps deck V an extended mono-green elf/power creep deck. The only pre-sideboard card which has any chance of dealing with something like Vigor is Tendrils (unless you're running Doom Blade/Hideous End/Feast of Blood for some reason). Beyond that, you've got to hope that your removal can keep up with the smaller creatures so your Gatekeepers can take care of the bigger ones. Not easy with cheap elves coming out every turn. ^^

So for anyone that ever questions why spot removal is so necessary - this is why. Creatures which simply *can't* be left alive.

140227: Vigor.author: Ralnakor
140227: Vigor.text_parsed:
@Kryptnyt - No. A third Vigor provides extra protection, but ultimately, the damage can only be prevented once, meaning the +1/+1 Counters are only placed that one time as the damage isn't prevented, say, three times as in your example.

Say I Pyroclasm with two Vigors in play along with, say, 5 1/1 Elf Tokens. Each creature in play will only get two +1/+1 Counters on them. It doesn't matter which Vigor prevented the damage, but once prevented, the other can't sweep in and prevent it again because there is nothing to prevent any more.

This card, when paired with the likes of any number of Graft creatures from Ravnica Block is absolutely monstrous. Next thing you know, that Cytoplast Root-Kin just became even more deadly than before.

@filmfanaticryan

I believe it would work the same as normal damage, Ryan. A creature with infect deals damage to creatures in the form of -1/-1 counters, and Vigor's ability states "if damage would be dealt to a creature you control other than Vigor, prevent that damage." So the damage is prevented as if it were damage from a normal creature, and the creature would receive no -1/-1 counters.
Hope that helps.


Anyways, about the card - I love it! It's pretty much game over for your opponent unless they can find a way to deal with him. And even if he dies, your other creatures would have probably been beefed up in the process. It's cards like these that make me wish Lorwyn packs weren't so hard to find these days.

140227: Vigor.author: CrowJonSnow
140227: Vigor.text_parsed:
i'm going to try and clear up a few questions i've seen

Infect: since vigor prevents any sort of damage, and infect DEALS damage in the form of -1/-1 counters, then infect would be useless, since all damage is prevented.

Blocking attackers who have trample: this works the same as protection from creatures. trample isn't based on damage dealt, it's based on damage ASSIGNED. all they have to do is assign lethal damage, then the rest goes through. when the actual damage would be dealt, you stop that to your creature, but the rest goes through.

hope that helps

140227: Vigor.author: HeartbreakerStudios
140227: Vigor.text_parsed:
This seems REALLY unbalanced.

A 6/6 for 6 mana is already par. Adding trample is fair. Adding self-recycling is better. Adding damage eating to all other creatures is WAY TOO GOOD.

Compare it to Phytohydra. Phytohydra doesn't have self-recycling or trample, and it's damage eating only applies to itself. At a cost of 5 it STARTS at 1/1.

Tack onto that that Vigor only needs Green and gets Elemental tribal bonuses, and you have a REALLY overpriced card.

The least they could have done was drop his power/toughness or up his cost.

140227: Vigor.author: Zielheim
140227: Vigor.text_parsed:
@Syberduh2

Incorrect, EVERY creature that has an ability basically reads 'this creature'. Otherwise, permanents that have abilities of other permanents without being copies of them wouldn't work. For example, if you had a Prodigal Pyromancer in your grave (and none on the field) and a Necrotic Ooze on the field, then going by your line of thinking, whenever the ooze activates it's ability, nothing would happen because there isn't a Pyromancer on the field. Likewise, if you had multiple Pyromancers out and activated it's ability, then all of the Pyromancers should be dealing damage because the ability states that "Prodgial Pyromancer deals 1 damage".

Effectively, every ability that ever specifies that creature (like Vigor or the Pyromancer), just read it as 'this creature' instead of '(insert creature's name)'.

@corranhorn84: Correct on the second count but not the first. When the text says Vigor it actually means "this Vigor." If it meant any Vigor, it would actually say "a creature you control not named Vigor" (see Detention Sphere).

You're correct about multiple Vigors not being cumulative - since the damange is prevented by one effect, the other effect does nothing.

140227: Vigor.author: Pongdok
140227: Vigor.text_parsed: This gets full marks due to the bizarre and excellent art. I don't think green needed this, to tell the truth. Most green beasties already have a fair bit of staying power, and making them all invincible, nay, better than invincible to damage is perhaps a bit much, particularly at 6 cmc with a 6/6 trample body. It may have been an effort to balance the scales, since green often gets the shaft. I had a casual game where an indestructible Kulrath Knight held off an entire Timmy army because my opponent had a Vigor. Quite amusing. 5/5 for style.

140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.author: sporvan
140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.text_parsed: A legend amongst Faerie kind, Wydwen always has a biting insult to unleash upon whoever crosses her stormy path. She comes and goes as she pleases and isn't concerned by anyone.  I only wish we knew more about her. As a card, she definitely is very good - fairly costed, surprising and great when you stack combat damage to return her to your hand. A pain for opponents to get rid of and fantastic in Limited. Unfortunately, there are so many other great Faeries in the 4 casting cost slot that she rarely manages to find space in decks. A pity because she's gorgeous and mysteriously cool!

140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.author: DacenOctavio
140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.text_parsed: She used to be much better pre-M10 combat damage rules. Damage used to go onto the stack; one would flash her in, block, and if she would be killed, her controller would just rescue her with her built-in bounce ability, which is why it costs life to do so. At the same time, the damage she would deal still got dealt to the attacking creature.

140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.author: Sootoo
140229: Wydwen, the Biting Gale.text_parsed:
This is a really neat EDH general for smaller games. She definitely deserves more than just 3 stars.
Comes great with equipments like Quietus Spike + enchantments like Wound Reflection, for example.

A good way to "abuse" her bounce and flash ability is also to put a lot of spells like Damnation or Black Sun's Zenith, for example, into your deck. This way you always can clean the board, if things get ugly, while still being able to rescue your general before it happens.

Although harder to protect, any games with above 3 players, I defenitely would prefer Oona over Wydwen, though. Anyway, really a lovely card (especially as a Commander)! 4.5/5

140230: Boggart Mob.author: Havrekjex
140230: Boggart Mob.text_parsed:
This is an amazingly good card in the right deck. Play Boggart Harbinger or preferably Goblin Matron, tutor Mob, play Mob next turn championing Boggart Harbinger. If Mob dies or is exiled, Boggart Harbinger comes back into play, and you get to fetch another goblin, preferrably another Mob so you can repeat the cycle.

It also comboes well with Wort, Boggart Auntie, since it has fear to trigger Mobs token generating ability, and since it can get your dead Mob back into play in addition to the one you get to tutor for when Boggart Harbinger/Matron comes back into play.

140233: Ajani Goldmane.author: Queen_of_the_Fae
140233: Ajani Goldmane.text_parsed:
I am surprised that the first white 'walker is rated so low?

Though he may not be THE BEST Spike-y card, he is wonderfully white.
People have often looked down upon whites biggest skills (damage prevention and life gain) and the thing is: Life gain and damage prevention buys you time until you kill your opponent.
And let's face it, if played right, white plays the best attrition wars.
And his first ability gives a nice, comfy 2 life every turn. A very nice cushion.

His second ability allows him to play more aggressively, pumping even only one creature again and again creates a situation that quickly demands to be dealt with. Not to mention how amazingly well this ability's synergy with persist-y creatures (in block too!) . . . I'm looking at you Kitchen Finks!

His last ability brings back so many wonderful memories of Urza's days . . . though, obviously not as good, but an Serra Avatar is still a deadly beast to behold (even if it is really easy to kill...).

A wonderfully good first foot to begin this new card type. And like most 'walker's abilities . . . his "build-up" ability and his "big" ability have amazing synergy with each other. (Gain lots of life and then poop out a huge Avatar token... and then gain some more life to make it even bigger!)

140233: Ajani Goldmane.author: SavageBrain89
140233: Ajani Goldmane.text_parsed: Ajani's first ability is useful although mabye not as powerful as some of the other first abilities of the other planeswalkers.  His second ability is amazing and downright lethal in creature and token decks.  And unlike other planeswalker situations where a person will have to decide wether to attack or keep thier planeswalker, Ajani makes both options available.  Even if Ajani is hit with a burn spell, as long as it doesn't kill him, it means the owner of him can gain small portions of live, making it harder for the opponent to kill them.  His last ability(a big creature with no trample or flying) is good, but really useless compared to his other two abilites which work amazing in token and life gain decks.  Overall one of the best planeswalker out there.

140233: Ajani Goldmane.author: Nytestryke24
140233: Ajani Goldmane.text_parsed:
The problem with the Avatar is that you people presume that your opponents are going to try and prevent you from getting a ridiculously powerful creature.

Besides, Negate > Planeswalkers ;)

Of course, Ajani is a cool card, and the 2 life gain does provide a nice cushion.
A friend of mine has him, and in the times that he's actually resolved, he hasn't played the -1 once.. I wonder why? The effects are permanent and much easier to get hold of several times than the Avatar. While the Avatar may be game breaking, why would anyone let you get a game breaking card onto the battlefield. (this can be prevented in many ways- Evasion (flying, unblockable, intimidate, fear), Bounce it, etc.)

The -1 ability can potentially be played turn 1, leaving with 3, and then restored back if not attacked.
All in all, a cool card, but not as great as some of you make him out to be ;)

140233: Ajani Goldmane.author: Silverware

I recently got my hands on one of these guys and I feel like out of all the planeswalkers this guy is one of the planeswalkers that gets ignored the most (not a bad thing).

For 4 mana you really are geting a pretty good deal, you can pump him to gain life and set your self up for his final, but this only works if you have a strong defence, and often the avatar won't be able to break through the lines.

I feel were the most power lies is with his seconed ability. You can use him to continusly boost all your creatures (great for white weenie decks) and make it so you can attack without worrying about leaving creatures as blockers. A very powerfull ability that is all to often overlooked.

Ajani Goldmane is an intresting planeswalker and one of my personal favorites. While many people consider him weak since he does not have an ability that ends the game when it goes off, what makes him great is that he has an ability that sets you up to win that can be used the moment he hits the field.

140239: Nova Chaser.author: littlebeast
140239: Nova Chaser.text_parsed:
@Mysteric: It doesn't HAVE to be... you could sacrifice the Chaser instead.

But yeah, practically speaking.

Also, want FUN TIMES? Put this on a Mimic Vat while you have an evoking creature out.

In fact you can use that as a way to cheat them into play (although they're usually not significantly cheaper, but it's still fun); evoke a creature, then in response to its sacrifice clause, pull the chaser off the vat. Boom, 10/2 trample haste, and when it dies you get your evoke creature again.

You can also do similar things with Kiki-Jiki, Splinter Twin, and such things, of course, but Mimic Vat is a bit more stable since the chaser doesn't have to survive.

140345: Changeling Titan.author: Japicx
140345: Changeling Titan.text_parsed:
I use this in my Giants deck. The dream play with it is: cast for three mana because of Stinkdrinker Daredevil. It's a 9/9 trampler due to Sunrise Sovereign. Equip it for free with Obsidian Battle-Axe, so it's now an 11/10 hasty trampler. The championed creature is Ondu Giant, so if it dies, I'll at least get another land out of my library. And then I might just Fling it.

Each of its characteristics proves to be extremely useful in this situation: its wacky cost-to-power ratio, its changeling and its champion. While championing a token seems like an obvious first choice, there are so many other options that are much more interesting and helpful.

Changeling creatures are awesome in Giant decks, because Giants have some of the most brutal tribal buffs. Changeling is one of the best ideas to come out of the Lorwyn-Shadowmoor period, because it stops tribal deck-building from getting dreadfully predictable.

Trader's friend: Dude, are you sure you want to trade that shiny Shimmering Grotto?
Trader: Yeah, why wouldn't I?
Trader's friend: Dude, it's shiny.
Trader: Dude, it's Shimmering Grotto.

141802: Shimmering Grotto.author: SleetFox
141802: Shimmering Grotto.text_parsed: This card fits a very critical role in casual Magic: the good but not super good five-color mana fixing common land. A fine-tuned land base has no use for a card like this, but when a player can't spend three digits on one deck before even adding spells, this is an awesome alternative, not unlike Terramorphic Expanse and Evolving Wilds. Its weakness is obviously that you risk slowing down early, but the cool thing about this (unlike with the common fetchlands) is that it's perfectly realistic to have completely smooth early game land drops with this.

In the early game, because of your lack of lands, you have a problem with getting the right colors, but late game that is not a problem because of the amount of land that you have. This cuts of your numerical amount of mana early game to provide you with colored mana, but that is often undesirable then losing 1 life. Remember, the only life that counts is your last.

141817: Austere Command.author: Keiya
141817: Austere Command.text_parsed:
I played this against a person who ran almost a pure artifact deck (artifact lands, creatures, everything). He didn't know what my deck was like and wasn't nervous until I slapped this in play and wiped his entire field except for two islands. He was looking at a Baneslayer Angel and a Serra Angel as his opposition, completely defenseless.
Definitely not as good overall as Cryptic Command for obvious reasons, but this card will still devastate your opponents in the right situations. Although in multiplayer, it's the most efficient command since every choice you have affects everyone and not just targets.

141817: Austere Command.author: JaxsonBateman
141817: Austere Command.text_parsed:
Today I played a fella using a 'defender' deck, with his wincons apparently Wakestone Gargoyle (allows defenders to attack) and Vent Sentinel (pings for damage = to number of defenders). He was also running a few artifacts, like Prophetic Prism for mana fixing, and Whispersilk Cloak for... expensive shroud and unblockability? *Shrug*

In any case, Austere Command along pretty much won the game for me. He had played out his hand except for one card. I had only played a Wall of Omens, and had 7 cards in hand. So not only did Austere Command kill everything of his but a Perimeter Captain and Stalwart Shield Bearers, but I got to keep my wall. =P

Yeaaah... when your opponent has 6 cards in hand to your none, and you don't have a sizable board advantage (or *any* board advantage), you're in for a tough day at the office. ^^

I love to use this guy in a WU infect deck! Blighted Agent becomes completly insane once this creepy alien hits the table! As long as you don't miss a land drop this is an easy 5th round win even if you get no other nasty creatures into play.
Round 1: Island

Round 3: any land, swing for 1 infect, play Mirror Entity (opponent at 1 poison)
Round 4: any land, activate entity for 4, swing for 4 infect (opponent at 5 poison)
Round 5: any land, activate entity for 5, swing for 5 infect (opponent at 10 poison)

141818: Mirror Entity.author: JaxsonBateman
141818: Mirror Entity.text_parsed:
I *love* the tribal shenanigans that this guy offers. Firstly, he can theoretically go in any Wx tribal deck, becoming a pseudo-lord in that he can pump the base P/T of your creatures for some massive damage. Then, he can create multi-tribal shenanigans by changing creature types. I've built a Bant 'every-tribe' deck, which uses him as an ideal lynchpin - essentially, depending on what tribal buffers you have out, you can get flying, lifelinking, shrouded, indestructible, unblockable creatures that make tokens and draw cards whenever they hit the opponent in the face (hint: slivers offer a lot of those).

And do you have any idea how hard it is for players to stop aformentioned creatures, given that 2 tribal lords (or a single pump sliver) means you can activated Mirror Entity for 0 and have all your creatures live?

141818: Mirror Entity.author: CFLuke
141818: Mirror Entity.text_parsed:
This card is a really powerful Spike and Johnny card. It is currently the finisher in a couple of my decks. My favorite is a Blue-White fishless fish deck where it can suddenly turn cheap blue fliers into nasty forces to be reckoned with. But I just had my best ever play with it...it was in the early game - I had out an Aether Vial which I left at two counters. I was in good position, controlling the game with five 1/1 or 2/1 creatures doing damage each turn.

I had tapped out all except one plains, and my opponent saw this as an opportunity to accelerate into a Bogardan Hellkite which would have caved the roof in on me. Oh man, the look on his face when I activated Mirror Entity with X=1, effectively converting all my creatures into Faeries, then tapped the Vial to put a Spellstutter Sprite into play, countering the Hellkite...

141819: Cryptic Command.author: Mode
141819: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
There are so many things you can do with this Command, this card is incredibly amazing and completely worth the cost.

It's like a cantrip version of Counterspell and Boomerang in one, plus you can also play those two effects without drawing a card instead, or even either prevent your opponents creatures one turn from attacking and/or make yours afterwards effectively unblockable - while still getting the option to a bounce, hardcounter or card draw.

That card is a constructed bomb and on the edge on being broken, yet as the Jitte rather very powerful than overpowered.

To quote Trancefo, that's indeed pure blue.

141819: Cryptic Command.author: a7141988
141819: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
I got a question about this card. So, suppose one guy plays Cryptic Command, choosing to counter a spell and bounce a permanent. Then, the other person, in response, uses Vedalken Mastermind (or something similar to that effect) to bounce the permanent that was targeted back to their hand. So, Cryptic Command lost its bounce target. So, does the whole spell fizzle or is the other spell still countered?

Also, this card is awesome, for the record.
141819: Cryptic Command.text_posted:
I got a question about this card.   So, suppose one guy plays Cryptic Command, choosing to counter a spell and bounce a permanent.  Then, the other person, in response, uses Vedalken Mastermind (or something similar to that effect) to bounce the permanent that was targeted back to their hand.  So, Cryptic Command lost its bounce target.  So, does the whole spell fizzle or is the other spell still countered?

Also, this card is awesome, for the record.

141819: Cryptic Command.author: klaff
141819: Cryptic Command.text_parsed:
@a714:

All of a spells targets must be illegal for a spell to fizzle, so the spell would still be countered. If, for example, they chose bounce a permanent and draw a card, and you bounced in response, the spell would lose its only target and would fizzle.
141819: Cryptic Command.text_posted:
@a714:

All of a spells targets must be illegal for a spell to fizzle, so the spell would still be countered. If, for example, they chose bounce a permanent and draw a card, and you bounced in response, the spell would lose its only target and would fizzle.

Wtf Wizards?

Let's switch the power levels of Cryptic Command and Incendiary Command.

Cryptic (the worst of the commands):
Counter target Sorcery spell
Return target creature to its owner's hand
Change all instances of a color word on target spell or permanent
Look at the top four cards of your library and put them back in any order
(I don't know if all of that text could fit on a card)

Incendiary (best command, $10, this would be an instant)
Deal 4 damage to target creature or player
Deal 2 damage to each creature
Destroy target artifact or land
(hmmm..... so far, this is still about $3)
Put a 5/5 red dragon creature token with flying in to play

hmmmm...... obviously and overly useful- I like it. Perhaps the dragon would actually be a 4/4.

141822: Ashling the Pilgrim.author: Oleander
141822: Ashling the Pilgrim.text_parsed: I have a really soft spot for Ashling the Pilgrim, namely for her neat ability. I find it incredibly fun to pump her up with tons of +1/+1 counter abilities, such as the Reinforce keyword or cards like Daily Regimen or Incremental Growth. I currently have a deck that utilizes Ashling's explosive properties with counters and Vigor's turn-damage-into counters function, which leads to great fun, as Ashling never dies and only gets larger each time she triggers.

141822: Ashling the Pilgrim.author: WotC_KennethNagle
141822: Ashling the Pilgrim.text_parsed: My first ever contribution to Magic was Ashling the Pilgrim's game text. She had no card after two rounds of emails, so I searched for red creatures with a colon ":" in their box and found Molten Hydra. I matched it closer to her Lorwyn novel synopsis (she explodes!). Card turned out neat, especially for Multiplayer which is an accomplishment for a red card. Nice art, we used it on booster packaging.
